Minister, doesn't this arrangement provide the government with extra leverage to demand that charities favourably comment when each instalment is paid—that is, not just once, but two or three times over the period of the grant?

—A very good interview.
—Yes, it was an exceedingly good interview, and I will share with you what he said on this matter because if you had heard him I doubt whether you would have asked the question. The Treasurer said:

answer.para: The whole objection—
the thrust of your question—

. . . was that people didn't disclose that they were being funded. So we put a clause in a contract requiring them to disclose. And what the contract says is, if you are running a seminar explaining GST, you must acknowledge that you've received a grant from the Commonwealth to do it if that is the case.

All we are trying to do is to make it clear to people that there is Commonwealth funding. Let me draw your attention to a comment by Mr Raper, the ACOSS President. Mr Raper is not someone who is traditionally noted as coming out—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are senators on my left interjecting and shouting. If you have some comment there is an appropriate time to debate it. You should not sit and shout all through question time.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht, I have just addressed you on the matter of behaviour.

answer.para: All it says is, if you are running a seminar, if you decide to run a seminar on tax compliance and the Commonwealth government has funded that seminar, then you should disclose that.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I never asked the minister about the Treasurer, I never asked the minister about Mr Raper and I never asked to be read long extracts from their speeches. I asked him a direct question that required a simple answer about the contractual terms the government is insisting on that charities sign up to in order to get public funding to help them convert to the GST.
—There is no point of order, Senator Cook; you are making a speech.
—The point of order is that the answer is not relevant to the question. Will you direct the minister to answer the question and not evade it?
—There is no point of order.

—I was going to speak on the point of order, but as you have ruled Senator Cook out of order I will not bother to. Senator Cook asked about the contract which charities are signing. My answer refers in detail to the contract which charities are signing and I am throwing Senator Cook's comments into an appropriate perspective. I urge Senator Cook to listen very carefully. It is always wise to listen to what the Treasurer says.

—Senator Kemp, direct your remarks to the chair.

—It is true to say that Senator Murphy is more successful at fly-fishing than asking questions and making policy comments in the Senate. That is the point I am making. Before I was so rudely interrupted by Senator Cook, I was saying that the fact of the matter is that charities are making comments on the GST and on a wide range of issues. We are always happy to consult with charities. As I have said so often in the past, we are a consultative government. The interpretation that you are putting on this contract, Senator, is entirely fallacious.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it true that the demand for favourable comment from charities in return for Commonwealth funding is unprecedented? Minister, this obligation has never been imposed on charities before, has it?

—I would have to check this but my understanding is that there have been similar clauses which have been included in contracts in the past. That is my understanding, Senator. But the whole nub of your question goes to whether charities are loath to comment on the GST. The short answer to that question is that charities are not loath to comment on the GST—you only have to look, Senator Cook, at the newspapers this morning and the newspapers yesterday. I think it is true to say that charities are quite happy and confident to comment on the GST; and I refer of course to the comments by Mr Raper, who is the President of ACOSS. So there we are: the question is fully answered in detail. I have been more than kind to you, Senator Cook.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

—I hear Senator Lundy talk about IBM. IBM is a company which has 5,000 Australian employees. It has offices in Sydney, Melbourne and Ballarat. They opposed our policies; they opposed the ANTS package lock, stock and barrel, as I recall. Senator Cook is nodding in agreement. Not an amendment was moved.

talk.start.para: —We opposed the GST.

—The truth of the matter is that you opposed tax reform but you are not prepared to state what you actually stand for. As I have said, the question was based on a faulty assumption, and Senator Cook should be more careful in the drafting of these questions.

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on both sides should observe the standing orders, as I have already said.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs. The government is committed to ensuring that the Australian Federal Police is strongly supported and is able to meet the challenges of the next decade. Will the minister inform the Senate of the government's ongoing financial commitment to the AFP?

—I thank Senator Watson for a very astute question. Commissioner Palmer, the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, recently said that the AFP has never enjoyed a higher reputation, has never enjoyed better funding and has never been more strongly supported by any government in its history. It has never been better funded and has never had a brighter future. Well may he say that. The Prime Minister said in February 1998 that Australia deserves a Commonwealth law enforcement agency that is second to none.

answer.para: As a consequence of the Prime Minister's commitment, we appointed Tony Ayers to do a review of Australian Federal Police funding. As a consequence, we have a new budget charter for the Australian Federal Police. We have committed more than $320 million of additional moneys to the Australian Federal Police to prepare it for the challenges of the 21st century.

talk.start.para: —You're still playing catch-up.

—Madam President, you might remind Senator Bolkus, before he again interjects, that the last year of Labor appropriations for the Australian Federal Police were for $207 million. This year the coalition have committed around $322 million to the Australian Federal Police. In the past 18 months we have committed $115 million to undertake a resources and skills upgrade program. That program is overseen by the Federal Police Monitoring Committee, which reports both to me and to the Minister for Finance and Administration. We have committed more than $100 million under the Tough on Drugs strategy to the Australian Federal Police, which is for four mobile strike teams, a heroin signature program, increased telephone interception, increased overseas liaison, computer upgrades, and money for more informants and for better handling of witnesses.

answer.para: In September this year, this government injected a further $105 million to dismantle the Australian Federal Police adjustment and cessation schemes. The AFP Adjustment Scheme, which we have bought out of, was the brainchild of guess who? The former Labor government. What a brainchild that was! They saddled the AFP with $105 million of debt, which grew every year, and refused to fund them for it. Where did they think they were going to get it? They would have to have taken it out of their operational funding. That was the brainchild of Labor—to give 70 per cent of the Australian Federal Police an incentive to leave. They gave 70 per cent of them an incentive to leave. And guess when? Just before the Olympics. That was the brainchild of Labor, and that was all they did for the Australian Federal Police. The Federal Police never found that regime appropriate to an ongoing professional employment relationship.

As a consequence of upgrading its operations, savings have been found to fund the new certified agreement. The certified agreement was reached after months of negotiation and is funded from existing AFP resources. It was overseen by the Industrial Relations Commission.

Recently the Federal Police paid a sign-on bonus of six per cent to its employees. Virtually all of the outdated allowances, penalties and overtime have been abolished in favour of a new incentive based remuneration package. It will enable the Federal Police to attract and retain highly skilled and qualified professionals in the face of increasing recruitment pressures. The new professional employment regime will substantially improve the effectiveness of the Australian Federal Police and will empower its officers to focus on getting the job done, and being paid well to do it, rather than placing inappropriate restrictions on what time of day the law enforcement can take place. That was the old system under the former Labor government. It is not the system that this government supports.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Far from not having any evidence, I want you to comment on this, Minister. talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In light of revelations about Acxiom, Geospend and the internal Australia Post survey, could the minister tell us whether this government will ever take action to provide privacy protection for the personal information of Australians? And hasn't it become clear to the government that even the existing public sector protections are not providing any real measure of privacy to the Australian public? Is it the case that the government's unwillingness to protect privacy as an internationally recognised human right will lead to a co-regulatory approach to privacy based on a similar framework to that which regulates commercial radio in Australia?

—I thank the senator for the question because it gives me the opportunity to clear up a few misunderstandings in the community, no doubt generated by the sort of dramatics that we have just heard from the senator. The government recognises the importance of privacy for the community and always has. Senator Stott Despoja would understand that. I think before you were in this place your party joined with the coalition parties in defeating the Australia card. So we need not listen to anybody on the other side about privacy. They wanted us all to have our own Australia cards. They have no credibility whatsoever. But we are, of course, committed to the importance of privacy to the community. Many people are concerned about the way personal information is used in the private sector, and we understand that.
—You're a disgrace.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, withdraw that remark.
—The minister is a disgrace because she is not telling the truth.
—You are not being asked to debate it, you are being asked to withdraw.
—I withdraw it.

—He is a good boy, Madam President, when he is behaving. This is the main reason, of course, why the government is committed to introducing legislation that extends privacy protection to the private sector. The bill is proposed to come into effect on 1 July 2001, or 12 months after its commencement, whichever is the latter. The bill will implement the national principles for the fair handling of personal information as the default national standards for the collection, use and disclosure of personal information.

answer.para: If a database of personal information is created by Acxiom and PBL before the bill commences, as media reports have indicated, it does not mean that it entirely escapes the new regime. With respect to personal information collected by an organisation before commencement of the legislation, it will oblige the organisation to take reasonable steps to ensure this data is accurate, correct and securely held. The organisation will also be required to be open to consumers about what information it already holds and how it collects, holds and proposes to use or disclose such information.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus, you have been persistently interjecting.

—Further, the bill will carefully prescribe the circumstances where an organisation may transfer personal information outside Australia in very limited circumstances. After the legislation has commenced, where existing data is updated by further collection of personal information, the organisation will need to comply with all the national principles, including those relating to the collection, access, use and disclosure of personal information.

answer.para: So, Senator, I hope that makes it clear to you that this government is committed to privacy legislation covering the private sector. The Attorney has made it clear on a number of occasions that that is the case. I have given you a bit more detail about how that is going to happen, and I invite you to take account of that next time you are making public remarks.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am wondering if the minister would describe the regime that she has just outlined as `light touch' as others in the community—and, indeed, her own government—have described it. And, given this so-called commitment to privacy, could the minister enlighten us as to whether or not this government is committed to securing communications privacy in Australia? Is it the case that, despite the rapid advances in monitoring and surveillance technologies, it is still the policy of the government to restrict access to encryption technologies and secure communications more generally? Does this government really believe that the information economy, which Senator Ellison was boasting about in answer to a previous question, can develop? answer.para: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator, there is no point in you gesticulating at me. I cannot hear you when I am talking and I have got no intention of giving you my time.

answer.para: If the Attorney has anything to add, I will certainly give it to you and I will give it to you quickly. But, as for referring to this as a light touch, it was your colleagues who told the papers last year that you were all sizzle and no sausage.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. —On 25 November, Senator McKiernan asked me a question in relation to some comments of Chief Justice Murray Gleeson and whether unrepresented litigants were dealing with state or Commonwealth laws. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator McKiernan asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 November 1999:

(1) Does the Minister believe that High Court Chief Justice Murray Gleeson is correct when he said that the Howard government's cutbacks to legal aid are causing problems of `substantial practical dimensions' which are threatening the efficiency of the Australian courts and their ability to deliver justice?
(2) Can the Minister indicate whether all of the unrepresented litigants were dealing in matters of state law or commonwealth law and why they were unrepresented?
Senator Vanstone—I referred the honourable senator's questions to the Attorney-General, who has provided the following supplementary information to the answers I provided at the time.
(1) Chief Justice Gleeson's remarks referred to the presence of unrepresented litigants in the court process.

The Government does not consider that there is empirical evidence to support the claim that there has been an increase in unrepresented litigants due to the Commonwealth's changes to the legal aid funding arrangements. Recent reports which indicate a different view rely on limited anecdotal evidence to support their claims.

There are a number of reasons why people may not be represented in court. People may choose to represent themselves, or they may fail to meet legal aid commission means and merit tests. Consequently, it is unlikely that those litigants would have qualified for legal aid funding in those circumstances, in any case.

The Commonwealth has maintained funding for legal aid in Commonwealth law matters at 1995-96 levels. The data available to us from legal aid commissions does not enable us to reach any conclusions regarding levels of self representation. However, the Government considers this is an important area which would benefit from more thorough research. The Australian Law Reform Commission is looking at this issue as part of its reference on the adversarial process with a discussion paper to be released early next year. In addition, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Finance have commissioned the Justice Research Centre to conduct research in the area of self funded litigants and is expected to report early next year. The Family Law Council also intends undertaking a project on litigants in person in the family law context and has formed a committee for that purpose.

(2) Information concerning whether matters before the High Court involving self represented litigants arise under Commonwealth or State law is not available from the legal aid statistics collection and would have to be sought directly from the High Court.

However, Commonwealth funding for legal aid services has not generally been used to support High Court litigation. Commonwealth legal aid funds are provided to assist those who are in most need, particularly for resolving disputes in relation to family law matters.

In any case, because of the diversity of factors which may determine whether or not a person is represented the information sought would not alone provide evidence of a link between self representation and changes to the Commonwealth's legal aid funding arrangements.

talk.start.para: —I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard some answers to questions asked by Senator Lundy on 30 November in relation to privacy issues.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—
Senator Lundy asked the Minister for Justice and Customs without notice, on 30 November 1999:

My question is to Senator Vanstone, Minister representing the Attorney-General. Minister, how does a member of the public prevent PBL from storing and selling their entire consumer spending history and credit details on the giant PBL axiom (sic) data warehouse?
Senator Amanda Vanstone—The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

1. There are, at the moment, strict rules in the existing privacy legislation that prevent credit providers and reporters from misusing and disclosing personal information contained in credit reports.
2. In respect of personal information contained elsewhere, there is currently no legislation that regulates the activities of private companies such as PBL and Acxiom.

3. This is not to say that the private sector is totally without regulation. Some industry bodies, such as the Australian Direct Marketing Association, have developed their own codes of practice. The Australian Direct Marketing Association Code has recently been authorised by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and binds all members of the Australian Direct Marketing Association. The Code sets standards for fair trading and contains privacy provisions to protect consumers. I understand that Acxiom is actively involved with the Australian Direct Marketing Association and adheres strictly to the ADMA code of practice.

4. Furthermore, in relation to PBL and Acxiom, there is nothing to prevent an individual from contacting Acxiom Australia at any time and asking it to remove that individual's personal information from its database. Indeed, Acxiom Australia would be wise to act on such a request, in the interests of good business and establishing a good relationship with consumers of Australia.

5. Even though the Acxiom Australia database may be established before the commencement of the proposed private sector privacy legislation, PBL and Acxiom will not escape the operation of this new regime. Some of the National Principles for the Fair Handling of Personal Information, which are contained in the legislation, will apply to personal information collected by Acxiom Australia before the commencement of the Bill.
6. Once the legislation is implemented, in respect of existing information, Acxiom Australia will be obliged to take reasonable steps:
- to make sure that the personal information it collects, uses or discloses is accurate, complete and up to date; and
- to protect the personal information it holds from misuse and loss and from unauthorised access, modification or disclosure; and
—to destroy or permanently de-identify personal information if it is no longer needed for any purpose.
7. As well, Acxiom Australia:

- must, on request, take reasonable steps to let individuals know, generally, what sort of personal information it holds, for what purposes, and how it collects, holds, uses and discloses that information; and
- may only transfer personal information outside Australia in very limited circumstances.

8. Where existing information is updated by further collection of personal information, Acxiom Australia will need to comply with all the National Principles, including those relating to the collection, access, use and disclosure of personal information.
Senator Lundy asked the Minister for Justice and Customs a supplementary question without notice, on 30 November 1999:

Minister, given that the Howard Government has consistently dropped the ball on privacy legislation covering the commercial sector, what is there to prevent other companies from accessing this database, which developers hope will contain the personal details of 15 million Australians? Isn't this just big brother keeping tabs on us via credit and spending details, but this time controlled by a private Australian company and a massive American information wholesaler?
Senator Amanda Vanstone—The answer to the honourable Senator's supplementary question is as follows:

1. I would first like to point out that I am most surprised by the honourable Senator Lundy's question, in the context of the Opposition's failure to do anything to protect the personal information of the private sector during its term in office. I also remind the honourable Senator of the Opposition's failed `Australia Card' proposal.

2. The Government has, since it announced that it would implement a `light touch' privacy regime for the privacy sector, gone to considerable lengths to take into account a broad and representative range of views in order to develop the best possible privacy regime for the Australian context.
3. Consultation has occurred in a number of forms since the Government's announcement in December 1998. It has proved very fruitful in developing the legislative framework.

4. The Government has decided to respond to recent calls for more consultation on the proposed legislation by agreeing to release key provisions of the Bill later this month to allow further consultation. These will include the National Privacy Principles, key definitions, exemption provisions covering the media and small business and the provisions covering personal health information. The Attorney-General proposes to introduce the Bill early in the first sittings next year.

5. Although there is currently no legislation that prevents other companies from accessing the Acxiom Australia database, there is nothing to stop an individual from contacting a direct marketing organisation to establish what information it holds about the individual and request that the organisation delete the information from its records.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Returned Services League

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) and the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked by senators today, relating to the goods and services tax and voluntary, charitable and service organisations.

Today we had one of the most extraordinary performances by the government. Not once in response to any number of questions from the opposition was it able to explain the implementation of the GST as it would affect voluntary, charitable and service organisations in this country.

The Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ducked completely in response to my question. She said, `Don't ask me. Ask the Assistant Treasurer.' Senator Newman's performance today in response to the question I asked proved what a helpless, hapless and hopeless minister she is. In response to an issue I asked about veterans and the RSL, the biggest veterans organisation in Australia, all she said was, though she represents the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, `Ask the Treasurer. Don't ask me.' That is appalling. It is an insult to the veterans community and all the veterans organisations.

It just shows that this minister, I suspect, has given up being a performer for the government. Most, if not all, ministers would welcome the opportunity to make a comment and answer a question about an issue that affects the veterans of this country. Not Senator Newman. In the past, she has been a shadow minister for defence and a shadow minister for veterans' affairs. When in opposition, she went around the place promoting herself as one of the experts on defence and veterans matters. But, as a minister representing the veterans' affairs minister in this place, she completely ducked the question. Why? Because she did not know or did not care. It is an insult.

Even if we had asked Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, about this matter, I suspect that we would have got the same answer in content as we got from Senator Newman, which was nothing. He would not be able to answer the question. There are several thousand RSL sub-branches around Australia, many of them with a turnover of less than $50,000 a year. They are, therefore, exempt.

talk.start.para: —I am glad that Senator Watson raises that point. The government is putting an amendment to make it $50,000. It is putting an amendment forward to reduce it from $100,000 to $50,000. It has not been debated yet; it is coming forward shortly. The several thousand RSL branches get an exemption. However, they are affiliated to a state organisation that has a turnover of several million dollars per year and a national organisation that has a turnover of several million dollars more. What is the government going to advise the RSL regarding local branches of the RSL in a suburb or town not having to pay the GST on the membership fees they charge?

speech.para: Eighteen months after the announcement of the GST, there is no information from the government on that. Even today, when the Treasurer, Mr Costello, was asked in a doorstop interview about how charities could get an exemption from the GST, his only advice was:

Well, they can structure their affairs so that they can take advantage of it on individual fundraising activities so that if a charity wants to stay outside the system, it is up to how it structures its activities.

What advice are you giving to the RSL on how it should structure itself at a sub-branch level not to pay the GST? If the RSL rang the Treasurer's office now and asked him for that advice, they would not get it. Any charitable organisation, or any other service organisation, would not get any advice from this Treasurer other than, `You go and work it out yourself.' It is a disgraceful proposition to put to charitable and service organisations in this community that they have to go and work out how they get around paying the GST. The minister is actually trying to make them some form of tax avoider. What he has proposed is ethically wrong. If he can say that only today, 18 months since they announced the GST, it is a disgrace. We now have seven months to go to the introduction of the GST and neither this Treasurer nor his representative here in this Senate can explain to the people or the parliament how this is going to work. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The wholesale sales tax system is really what the opposition are supporting, because they have no other policies. I remind honourable senators that, some time ago in this chamber, I referred to a friend of mine who had manufactured a product and had not charged wholesale sales tax because he believed it was not necessary. He was followed up by the tax office some years later for a bill of something like $275,000 or an amount of that sort. When he challenged the tax office and said that he had involved other businesses that were selling that product after he had stopped making it and they were not charging wholesale sales tax, he was asked if he would sign an agreement that he still owed the money but if he did not tell anybody about it or publish the agreement, he would not have to pay the money. That was the sort of blackmail that was going on under Labor.

speech.para: Under the wholesale sales tax, there was the argy-bargy about in-ground swimming pools and above-ground swimming pools. In-ground swimming pools were deemed not to attract wholesale sales tax, although wholesale sales tax had been charged on them for years and years and had to be rebated. It was a ramshackle, appalling system. All the Labor Party can do is to come in here today and to go on and nitpick.

They go on about charities, but I want to remind them that just before Christmas 1993, just before a federal election—I remember it because I was here—Mr Keating made a promise to charities that they were going to match dollar for dollar every dollar that was raised by that charity. What a scam. What a bogus scam. When the charities looked at the fine print, they were going to get a dollar for every dollar that they spent of that money that was raised over the Christmas period. As the charities said to me, `We raise the money at Christmas and we spend it for the whole of the year till the next Christmas. We can't spend it all at Christmas or we would not have anything left, because we don't get as much in our winter appeal.' Some of them do not even have winter appeals. The Labor Party, which are now bleating about charities, absolutely hoodwinked the charities in 1993. It was a disgraceful hoodwinking of those charities.

Now we have the Labor Party peddling myths and untruths about the GST. They are saying it is an insidious tax. Let us go back to what the Labor Party said historically about the GST. Mr Hawke went on and on about it being a good tax. Mr Keating went on and on about how important it was as a tax. Mr Hawke said in 1985:

Unless there is a source of income in the consumption area, then the mass of Australians—the ordinary taxpayers—are not going to be able get the substantial cuts in personal direct taxes to which they are entitled.

He is absolutely right. We are having huge tax cuts from which people will be able to have more discretionary income to donate to charities. They will be able to assist in a greater way. It is absolutely amazing for the Labor Party to come in here and nitpick about the GST when they have no policies themselves. If I have time, I will say a bit more about Labor's view of the GST.

Labor are coming in here peddling myths and untruths, saying, `What is going to happen about the Girl Guides at a lamington drive?' The Assistant Treasurer has been saying over and over again that they can structure them in a way that enables them to earn up to $100,000 without having to deal with the GST. That is a lot of lamingtons. I have done lamington drives for the Girl Guides. I know about having the netting thing across the hall, getting the sponge and dipping it in the chocolate. We never made $100,000 and we worked our tails off in a weekend. If a church is running a fete and they want to have the cake stall and other stalls, they can structure them as separate entities and raise the $100,000. If they can raise $100,000 on the white elephant stall and $100,000 on something else, then good luck to them. They can structure it. I am sure the Guides and the Scouts and the charitable organisations have the wit and the will to structure, if they wish to, so as not to pay GST.

I have not heard the Labor Party say that if they got into government they would get rid of the GST. The Labor Party would serve the Australian public better if, in a cooperative way, they looked at the ways in which to implement this taxation system—the greatest reform of tax since federation—to ensure that we can actually provide health, social security and all the things we need to provide, as a compassionate society, into the future and to enable young Australians in the future to provide for the older people in their communities and for the health of the nation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The way that the government has proceeded in relation to handling this issue on the taxation of charities does not surprise us on this side of the Senate. In the last few years we have seen conflict between the Labor side of politics and the non-Labor side of politics—and this includes the Democrats. Once again, we are seeing a bit of a conflict between people who are motivated by being well-meaning, by generosity of spirit, and, in this case, as usual, the coalition, who the Society of St Vincent de Paul described as mean spirited. Time and time again over the last few years since Labor lost power we have seen this conflict between people who are motivated by this generosity of spirit and those who are mean spirited.

speech.para: Over the last few days a number of organisations have come out quite strongly against the federal government and what they are planning to do in relation to this taxing of charities. There is World Vision, which I mentioned in my question to Senator Kemp today. Senator Denman mentioned Adelaide Central Mission, in which, as I understand it, elderly volunteers repair donated dolls for resale; the chief of the mission believes that that will result in a tax that they will have to pay. We also have the Royal Life Saving Society, whose chief executive has slammed the situation in relation to this tax, because he does not believe that he will find any volunteers to act as treasurer to organise compliance with and administer this tax.

Catholic Health Australia and Mr Francis Sullivan have said that to comply with and administer this act, on the advice of Arthur Andersen, a consulting group, would cost them $69 million extra a year. And to cap it all off, Mr Terry McCarthy, a spokesman for the Society of St Vincent de Paul, said that to them it will mean that they will have to pay another $1 million a year to comply with these GST rules. To quote Mr McCarthy:
That's $1 million less to distribute to the poor, the disadvantaged and the disenfranchised.

What I cannot understand is why the government are acting in such a mean spirited way. I do not understand what motivates them to carry on in this way. All I can think is that there is some sort of extreme Calvinism running deep through their ranks that means that they believe that the poor, the disadvantaged and the disenfranchised are there because they are poor, disadvantaged and disenfranchised; that it is their fault that they are not part of the elect and therefore they should be punished one way or another: there should be no rewards and they should have a stick taken to them to make sure that they get out of this situation that they have unfortunately found themselves in.

I do not know of any members of the coalition who would know that sometimes people find themselves in this desperate situation where they have to humbly go and ask for assistance, which is not an easy thing, I imagine, for Australians to do. It takes courage for them to do it, and they do it. There are men and women out there in our country who volunteer and put in a lot of time and energy, and their own money, to make sure that their fellow Australians are not poor, disadvantaged or disenfranchised.

Why are the charities upset? Because the government went to the last election and said that charities would not be taxed. They fibbed to them. They misled them. No wonder the charities are upset about it. There are five representative groups, and that is only from some of the press clippings in which you can see that this is the situation. We on this side say to the government and to those charitable organisations that we are concerned about where they are coming from. What we would ask the government—and Mr Swan, our shadow minister for family and community services, has urged the Prime Minister to do this—is: why don't they do the decent thing and exempt charities and their fundraising activities from the GST net? That is all the government have to do to end this scandal. But they will not, because they have misled the people that they said would be exempted from this taxation, and they are going to continue to do that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is not a case, as Senator Hutchins said, of the government misleading charitable organisations. For the record, it has always been the intention of all governments to ensure that the taxation pool is not diminished, not just by individuals but by charities that do not conform to a certain set of rules. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have made it quite clear that the pursuit of tax dodgers is one of the government's great successes since its time in office. To suggest otherwise of this government—this caring government, this government that has captured the hearts and the minds of the blue-collar workers, the people that used to support that other side of politics—is ridiculous.

speech.para: For instance, Senator Hutchins went on about the aged, the infirm, the fragile and the young, as did other speakers, when that is not the intention of the government, nor is it true. This government in fact makes it easy under the GST for over 80 per cent of the people of Australia to have tax cuts. Why would it—looking at it rationally—try to take away those areas of responsibility that are assumed by the private sector and then have to come in itself and fill in that vacuum? I must say that, before Senator Hutchins's time, the Treasury, during the Hawke-Keating government, was run by fiscal bandits. We had an enormous job to do to repair that damage. But it will be nothing like what we will see, even though the success is as great as it has been for this government, this Howard coalition government of the Liberal Party and the National Party. The success is coming with the implementation of the GST. And when it comes, charitable organisations will be better off. Every other organisation in Australia will be better off.

Perhaps they will still be dependent. By their very nature, by their very name, they are dependent on charity, and this government has never closed its eyes to charitable organisations, has never closed its eyes to people in need. I only have to point out what happened in East Timor recently, when it was this government that solved the problem there, when it was the initiative of this Howard government that sent in those brave young Australians to restore order there, at the risk of their own lives. We talk about the grand picture but we do not let the micro picture go aside either. There is one thing that this government has a preoccupation with, and that is those people in need. Let me tell the other side that the GST legislation already contains concessional measures that are available to charities. We have already put that in print. We have already put there the registration turnover threshold of $100,000 GST free, the GST-free status of non-commercial activities and the GST-free status of supplies of donated second-hand goods.

What really turns my stomach in this argument is the fact that a picture is painted to try and stampede people into believing that the GST is going to be on some broken-down dolls that may be repaired by people with the utmost care and the utmost feeling for those people who are deprived, that somehow having people carry out charitable work on charitable donations is going to attract the GST. It is quite clear that the legislation provides for those things to be GST free, and I think that is a scare tactic, notwithstanding that it is incorrect, and forgets the big picture of the GST. Don't look at the hole, look at the donut, and the donut is that not only charitable organisations will be better off but all Australians will be better off. We have got $12 billion of tax cuts coming in on 1 July next year. We have got $2,000 to $3,000 coming off motor vehicles next year. In three out of four years since we have been in government, we have had record sales of motor vehicles. The scare tactics that the Labor Party so assiduously use need to be rebutted, and rebutted they will be. You cannot take the voting public of Australia for fools. You have done it for far too long and it is going to end. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to take note of the answers given by Senator Kemp on the GST and charities. The Howard government relied on the mantra that no-one would be worse off under a GST. What are we finding? We are finding that one of the vital partners of the Howard government's so-called coalition, the charitable sector, will be worse off. Despite what Senator Lightfoot said, we have heard many examples of how they will be worse off.

speech.para: One of the other partners of his so-called social coalition are the CEOs on those massive salaries. I have not heard them complain. Why should they? After all, they have computer programmers and experts on tax law setting up the compliance mechanisms. This will be left to their underlings and they will reap the benefits of the massive tax cuts. Thus we find that business will be able to claim compliance costs, for example, a new computer. Charities have never paid tax on a new computer, so they are not going to benefit. Business will also benefit from not paying wholesale sales tax. Charities have never paid it, so again there is no benefit to the charity; but there is to business. Additionally, charities will not benefit from the reduction of tax in the same way that business will.

Compliance is one of the real issues for charities, who even now have trouble finding treasurers for their management committees. We have to realise that charitable organisations rely on volunteers. How will those dedicated volunteers find the time or the energy to do all the extra work, again in their spare time? The Howard government will make mileage from the free courses that they are offering to these groups. That is fine for people in business. They can pay someone else to substitute for them while they do the free courses. Charitable groups cannot, be cause again they rely on volunteers to come in. They cannot pay people to substitute for them while they go off and do these courses, so again it is volunteers who are at the moment giving extended time and may not have the time to go on giving that extended time. I spoke today with a charitable service provider in my area on the north-west coast of Tasmania, and one of his main concerns is where they are going to find volunteers to reprogram their computers and how they are going to call on their already overburdened treasurer to pick up the slack from the extra work that the GST will provide for them.

Confusion still reigns over what will attract a GST and what will not. I think Senator Kemp totally misunderstood the question I asked about the dolls being repaired by the dolls hospital for the Adelaide City Mission. We still do not know whether they will or will not attract the GST. We have found that new goods donated will attract a GST but second-hand goods donated will not. So the logical thing to do, if you are given new goods, is ask the donor to give them elsewhere so that wherever else you give them can give them back to you as second-hand goods and they then do not attract the GST. Raffle tickets will not attract the GST but school fundraisers such as lamington drives and chocolate sales will. One could imagine charities saying, `Please give these new goods to somebody else so that we can have them back,' and that is going to create a most awful mess.

As I have already said, raffles do not attract a GST, so why hold stalls? The Labor Party would be delighted that raffles do not attract a GST, and the Labor Party raised lots of money through our membership with raffles. If that does not attract a GST, that will probably suit us very nicely. The President of ACROD, Michael Sumner, put out a statement today and in it he said, `There is no doubt charities will be worse off in comparison.' (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Stott Despoja today, relating to private sector privacy laws.

I asked Senator Vanstone today about privacy and in particular about the dire need for Australia to have a comprehensive, national and preferably enforceable privacy regime so that all Australians can feel confident that their personal information and data are protected, especially in light of events in the past week. We have seen the Acxiom debacle in relation to data warehouses. We have seen the Geospend issue. We have seen even this morning allegations about the HIC. There is also the internal Australia Post health survey. All of these issues have brought the privacy debate fairly and squarely onto the public agenda, yet we have yet to see any comprehensive action by this government.

One thing Senator Amanda Vanstone said in response to my question was quite correct—and I do acknowledge that—and that was the Labor Party's history on this. There were some latecomers to the privacy debate on the opposition benches today who were getting quite agitated about the issue of privacy. I certainly appreciate their agitation in the sense that we have yet to see the extension of the Privacy Act to the private sector. Unfortunately, opportunities for the Labor Party in office to strengthen and tighten privacy laws were not taken advantage of.

At the risk of giving a brief history lesson, I think it is important to understand the context of this debate in Australia. I am certainly very proud of the history of the Australian Democrats. As Senator Vanstone pointed out in her response to my question, yes, we did join with the then opposition to defeat the Australia Card during the 1986 debate. During that time, it generated a great deal of awareness among Australians about privacy issues. The bill of former senator for the Australian Democrats, Senator Michael Macklin, in 1987 brought on the debate that culminated in the Privacy Act in 1988. At that time, the Australian Democrats tried, through amendments, to extend the Privacy Act not only to the public sector but to the private sector—a debate that is ongoing. Amendments put by former leader Janine Haines to ensure the protection of personal information in the private sector were opposed on that occasion.

We have introduced a private member's bill in the last few years. In 1997, my private member's bill would have extended the Privacy Act to the private sector. We withdrew that bill after the government finally decided that it would act to ensure some degree of private sector privacy. In fact, the government did promise during its 1996 election campaign that this would be a priority issue. I note that at the last election the coalition's policy stated:
The coalition regards personal privacy as a cherished right in a free society.

The government claimed that it would `work with industry and states to provide a co-regulatory approach to privacy within the private sector in Australia comparable with the best international practice.'

Indeed, the evidence in the answer today indicates that the government has been consulting, and we acknowledge that, through the privacy principles consultations. We are very pleased to be a part of that process. Consultation has taken place, but that is not enough. Consultation is good, but it is not an excuse for holding up the protection of privacy. I did note that some members of the opposition screamed and shouted during the answer to the question, but they have a worse record. When Senator Bolkus was the joint sponsor of a motion to refer the issue of private sector privacy to a Senate committee with me, he certainly indicated a willingness to rectify this record. But Labor was the party that introduced the Australia Card in 1986 while in government. It was the party which did not support the extension to the private sector of the Privacy Act in 1988. There seems to be a different policy from the opposition depending on whether or not it is in government.

talk.start.para: —A bit like you on the GST, isn't it?

—Not like me on the GST. I acknowledge that there is time for the ALP to change its mind, and I hope that it will join with us in urging the government to get its act together on the issue of privacy and extending it to the private sector. The Democrats believe that personal information should be protected through a comprehensive and national enforceable regime. We believe the fundamental principle that a person has the right to know what personal information is held about them, whether the information is lawfully held and, of course, whether or not that information is correct. Article 17 of the International Charter of Civil and Political Rights provides:

speech.para: . . . no one shall be subject to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his [or her] privacy.
We have seen evidence to the contrary in the last few months and weeks, and it is time for decent laws. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —The President has received a letter from Senator Woodley proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The need for the government to implement without delay the recommendations of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee's report into the deregulation of the Australian dairy industry.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I will ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

—The reason why I have proposed this matter of public importance today is that there is great concern about this issue in the dairy industry and amongst dairy farmers. Last week I attended three meetings on this, as well as being here for sittings of the Senate. One of my representatives attended another meeting and I have further requests for meetings in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. There is significant concern in all of those states—and in fact in every state of Australia—about this matter. The meetings which I attended included Victoria. I say that because it has been very interesting to listen to some of the rhetoric about this issue which says that all of the farmers in Victoria are behind deregulation. Certainly in the meetings I attended the concern was about half and half—half of those present supported deregulation and half did not. A rough poll taken by Channel 9 at a meeting in Shepparton showed about 55 per cent of the audience against deregulation and about 45 per cent in favour. We know of course that the Victorian government itself will be entering the debate in the sense that there will be a plebiscite in the next couple of weeks for which a question has been prepared. The plebiscite will be taken amongst Victorian dairy farmers.

speech.para: Today I want to look at the various recommendations of the report and put them into the context of the rest of the report so that people will understand how they have come about. Then I hope to convince the Senate and perhaps put pressure on the government to respond to those recommendations, because I believe they are critical to this whole debate about deregulation. The package which the government has announced is inadequate, and without implementation of the recommendations of our report, I believe, the action for deregulation will indeed mean disaster for the Australian dairy industry.

The first recommendation urges the Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, to call as a matter of urgency a meeting of state agricultural and regional development ministers to determine a framework and a time frame for the coordinated deregulation of the dairy industry. I believe that the Commonwealth has not taken sufficient action in this regard. Whether that is the fault of the Commonwealth or the states has been a matter of great debate, but I certainly support the recommendation of the committee that this meeting be called. It should have been called by now, and it must be called as soon as possible.

The concern I have is that the states are acting independently of one another and, in some cases, acting independently of the Commonwealth. That Victoria is moving to a plebiscite illustrates that. Farmers in other states would also like to have some kind of plebiscite, so there is a need for a national approach. Certainly in the meetings I attended in Victoria, there was a small—and I want to emphasise the word `small'—but vocal minority who were saying, `We don't care about the rest of Australia. We're going to benefit.' I am sure that that is not a universal or even a majority opinion, but it was said strongly. I was very disappointed in that because I believe the dairy industry in Australia is a national industry and must take account of the concerns of all the states.

There is division not only between the states but also within the states. That was particularly clear to me in Victoria, where there is a tremendous amount of bitterness between farmers, depending on which side of the debate they are on, and even between regions. With that and with the divisions between the states, there is an urgent need for all of the states and the Commonwealth to come together to address these issues. There is need for a unified industry and, particularly, for solidarity amongst farmers. If there is not that solidarity, then I believe they will be picked off one by one to their own detriment and to the detriment of this country.

The report, as background to this recommendation, suggested that there are winners and losers. Under the current regulation, under the system we have at the moment, the winners are the farmers, who get a decent return for their work and investment, and the consumers, who have a regulated and guaranteed year-round supply of milk and a price which is not only reasonable but, as has been pointed out on many occasions, below the cost of water.

talk.start.para: —So you are against deregulation?
—I am against deregulation. Hadn't I made that clear?
—You hadn't said.
—I will get to that.
—Order! Senator McGauran, you are on the speakers list, so wait your turn.

—Under the current system, the other lot of winners in this whole issue are regional economies. One of the big concerns expressed in our report is the effect of deregulation on regional economies where the main income is dairying. We can refer to the studies done in the Bega Valley and in one of the shires in Western Australia, the name of which I cannot quite remember at the moment. Perhaps Senator Crane might be able to tell us.
—Try Boya.

—Right. They have shown a significant loss for regional economies following deregulation. It is this whole issue of winners and losers which makes it absolutely critical that we pick up recommendation 1 of that report and that this meeting is held as soon as possible.

speech.para: Another concern in the report was the shift of control and income away from farmers to processors, manufacturers and the large retailers. One of the things which the report said was that the market or commercial pressures will force deregulation. I have made clear that, although it was a unanimous report, I had a reservation at that point. I do not believe that deregulation is inevitable, and I want to return to that a little bit later in this speech.

The other recommendation supported this initial one. Recommendation 2 pointed out that there could be penalties from the National Competition Council if there is any delay in deregulation. I do not agree with that proposition and neither does the committee. Recommendations 3 and 4 pointed out that where there is a loss of quota, as there is in three states, this is a loss of real property and that, where there are regional impacts, these also should be compensated. So we are worried that the package does not address the issue of the loss of quotas or the issue of regional impacts. We recommended that the ACCC monitor the effects on consumers and farmers. That is critical.

Finally, in recommendation 6, having heard claims during the hearings of some of the accountability and transparency processes within some of the large cooperatives, we recommended that an inquiry into the operations and accountability mechanisms of cooperatives be undertaken. I have already begun to do some work in that regard.

Let me finish with a couple of concerns. I am concerned about the Victorian plebiscite because I believe the question which has been posed to farmers is a very loaded question. We warned about that in our report. We said that you should really have a national, professionally prepared survey, not a single question which is too easy to bias. Is deregulation inevitable? No, it is not. It is only a lack of political will to stand against commercial pressures which will make it inevitable. I want to say that it is about time that we realised that in this place we represent people; we do not manage on behalf of powerful corporations. What is the point of standing for election to parliament or to a peak body unless we are prepared to represent the people whom we say we stand for? I urge the government to act now before we lose another one of our primary industries unnecessarily. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this matter of public importance relating to the deregulation of the Australian dairy industry and to address the recommendations of the committee, of which Senator Woodley was the chair and of which I and other senators in the chamber, including Senator O'Brien, were members. Senator Calvert attended a number of hearings, as did Senator McGauran.

speech.para: I found the contribution of our chair somewhat of a contradiction, in that he combined his personal views with the findings of the committee. I do not think there are any of us here who do not support the motion. Certainly the government supports it. It is rather interesting that we have before us an MPI put by the Democrats that we support. The problem I have with Senator Woodley's contribution is that the report made it quite clear that— whether or not we liked it, and whether or not we had a personal view—deregulation of the dairy industry was inevitable. There were a number of reasons for that, but the most important one, when talking about national pools or DMSS schemes, is that the dairy farmers themselves, particularly in the outlying states, did not support a return to either of those schemes, and there is no viable alternative.

It needs to be understood that, if all the states decided not to deregulate, milk would flow from the various business operations across state borders, whether it be from cooperatives or from businesses. The impact of that would be to deregulate the price at the selling point, so the impact would be there regardless of what the states did. The important thing is that there is agreement between the states and the Commonwealth to implement the Commonwealth package and some of the other issues in our report. I quickly wish to deal with those issues. The first recommendation says:

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services and the Federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Government call as a matter of urgency, a meeting of state Agriculture and Regional Development Ministers to determine a framework, and a timeframe, for the co-ordinated deregulation of the Dairy Industry.

The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Truss, has arranged a meeting on 22 December of all state agricultural ministers to determine a framework and a time frame for the coordinated deregulation of the dairy industry. This is the fourth time in the last five months that there has been an endeavour to put together such a meeting. The date is 22 December, which is the day after the Victorian poll result will be announced, and it reflects the urgency and priority that the minister has placed on this issue.

Had the Victorian poll been earlier, the meeting would have been held earlier, but it was deemed by the various state ministers and the federal minister that it would be better to hold that meeting after the poll result was known, and that arrangement is in place. The second recommendation says:

That should administrative arrangements not be in place in time to make the first payments by 1 July 2000, that appropriate compensatory arrangements are factored into the payments schedules, in order that dairy farmers do not suffer any more financial hardship than is presently envisaged.

The government's response to that is that it plans to have the administrative arrangements in place in time to make the first payments by 1 July. Of course, this is dependent to a degree upon the outcome of the ministers' meeting on 22 December, but I have been informed that they will go into that meeting with strong goodwill.
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw smiles. I have been informed that it even includes the New South Wales minister. At least we are getting cooperation from New South Wales. I believe that the only thing that would delay that process would be if it were held up in the political process here, and I do not believe that will happen. Recommendation 3 says:

speech.para: That the states of Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia consider the issue of quota entitlement and any form of compensation that may be appropriate for the resumption of quota entitlement, including the possibility of using the NCP payments as compensation.

As we all know, this is an issue for the states, but I can tell you that at this point in time the minister for agriculture in Western Australia has invited the dairy industry there to prepare a submission to him dealing with that particular issue. I hope there is similar action taking place in New South Wales and Queensland, but I do not know at this point whether that is the case. Maybe some other people in the debate can assist us in terms of that particular discussion.
The fourth recommendation of the committee says:
That regional adjustment packages for rural and regional communities affected negatively by deregulation be developed by both State and Commonwealth Governments.

This is a matter on the agenda of the ministers' meeting. There has been communication between the minister's office and the various state ministers' offices to address that particular aspect. Hopefully, some guidelines will flow from that and subsequent meetings of officials. We move over the page to recommendation 5:

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission in accordance with subsection 17[1] of the Prices Surveillance Act monitor costs and prices in the dairy industry so that dairy farmers are not unfairly burdened with the cost of the proposed levy.

I am informed that Minister Truss has proposed that the ACCC be resourced to monitor milk prices during the deregulation process and to deal with the substance of this particular recommendation from the committee. Finally, recommendation 6 says:
That an inquiry into the operations and accountability mechanisms of cooperatives be undertaken.

The government asked what purpose such an inquiry would serve our commercial operations. However, the minister has made it clear that this is a separate issue from deregulation and certainly something that he is prepared to have a look at.

Basically, I have gone through the recommendations that were made by the committee and, might I say, without apportioning blame, that at long last we will get the meeting which I think everybody here would liked to have seen happen a month or two ago but for some reluctance by some of the participants. Then the decision of the new Victorian government to have a plebiscite delayed it further. If they work diligently and cooperatively, it is my view that in fact they can deal with the issues in the time that is allowed.

Finally, in answering particular aspects of this MPI, it is worth noting that the committee report was tabled in parliament with the unanimous support of the whole committee—ourselves, the Labor Party and the Democrats. That underscores the constructive nature of the inquiry we held. It was not an easy inquiry. In fact, it was very difficult. People who are used to situations that they have lived with for a long time find it hard to cope with the deregulated environment, with the new world.

The Senate needs reminding—as I have done in a number of meetings that I have addressed in a number of states since the inquiry—that it was the Kerin plan and then the Crean plan which inevitably led to this particular day with the huge emphasis on the development of our export market. The reality is that export market production has now overtaken domestic market production and commercial pressures have brought this day upon us when the dairy industry will be deregulated, regardless of what individual states do. I do not criticise that. I think that is something that we must accept. There was a certain amount of political driving from within the industry itself and also from within this parliament to bring about this day. There are going to be some enormous adjustments and the structural adjustment package will be absolutely crucial for some towns—I mention particularly Harvey, a town just north of Bunbury in Western Australia where the committee held hearings. They have other problems with the restructuring of the forest industry in that part of Western Australia. We as a government, along with the states, need to be responsive to what is required to deal with those adjustments.

Having said that, this package of the federal government that is worth some $1.8 billion is still on the table. It is funded through a consumer levy. What happens in terms of the regional projects, the regional submissions and the regional restructuring is something that will have to be determined in a joint operation between the Commonwealth and the states. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! I would like to recognise in the public gallery former Tasmanian member of the House of Representatives for Wilmot and Lyons, Max Burr, and welcome him to the Senate.
—Hear, hear!
