As Dr Wooldridge indicated in the House of Representatives, it is the government's intention that this be transparent and that ANZFA be fully accountable. A commitment has been given that ANZFA will consult with key stakeholder groups in developing the appropriate regulations.

This bill is the result of careful consideration by ANZFA and of consultation by ANZFA with key stakeholders. The opposition, as I mentioned earlier, proposed amendments in the House of Representatives which were broadly in line with the government's policy intent and, as a result, they were accepted. I am confident that the bill, as amended, will meet the needs of consumers and industry alike. The bill emphasises ANZFA's role in ensuring the protection of public health and safety and in protecting consumers from misleading or deceptive behaviour. The bill will also ensure consumers have enough information about food to enable informed choices to be made.

Finally, the bill will benefit all stakeholders by ensuring that government appropriated money is used for the primary purposes of public health and safety protection and protection of consumers whilst ensuring that applications of direct financial benefit or urgency to industry are assessed in a timely manner. I thank senators for their contributions and for their indications of support, and I thank the Labor Party for its support in the House of Representatives after the amendments were adopted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —I will be moving a series of amendments to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill [No. 2] 1999 on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I take on board the suggestion that Senator Brown made in his contribution—that the precautionary principle was a principle to which the authority should subscribe. The idea of an amendment to the Democrats amendment No. 3 is acceptable. I will be moving that in due course. I move Democrat amendment No. 1:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (line 29), at the end of the definition of code of practice , add "However, a code of practice is not a standard.".

This amendment relates to the voluntary code of practice. This amendment seeks to clarify that codes of practice are not considered in the same light as food standards. In my comments in the second reading debate I made quite clear that the Democrats do not consider codes of practice a substitute for food standards. This amendment that I am proposing is to ensure that the differentiation between statutory food standards and industry developed codes of practice—COPs—is stated in the bill. Codes of practice and food standards should not be clustered together under the one generic term of `food regulatory measures' without at least some clarification.

The ANZFA amendment bill enables the ANZFA to formally manage COPs in a manner akin to that of applications and proposals to ANZFA for the variation and creation of new food standards. However, the ANZFA's management is not reviewable through the traditional mechanism of a food regulatory system. The major difference between food standards and voluntary codes of practice is that the ANZFA will have the final approval powers for any new code of practice. The Australia New Zealand health ministers—that is, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council—are not required under the bill to approve the bill and cannot veto it. As codes of practice avoid public input provisions, such as meetings of the Australian health ministers, and are voluntary, the Democrats maintain that we should do something about the chasm of difference between the two measures. The Australian Democrats maintain that voluntary codes of practice are not an adequate protection of public health. This amendment seeks to fix that.

talk.start.para: —I support that amendment. If I hear correctly, what Senator Stott Despoja is saying is that a code of practice is not a standard and she does not want a COP to end up being a COP-out, and I would agree with that.

—I note the amendment put forward by Senator Stott Despoja, and would comment that this amendment acts only to state the obvious. It is not necessary and it is not good drafting practice. The fact that the act has a separate definition of `standard' is sufficient to indicate that standards and codes of practice are different.

—I rise to support the Democrat's amendment which sets out the difference between standards and codes of practice. I would like to elaborate on some of the reasons why it is very important that the people who are assessing clearly understand the difference between the two. When we look at the whole food spectrum, we are looking not only at conventional foods that we consume today. We are also looking very closely at the make-up of those foods. With the dynamic changes that are happening in genetic manipulation and the predominance of chemicals that are used in the preparation and growing of those foods, the codes of practice have to be looked at from an entirely different aspect; that is, whether they are sufficient enough to ensure that matters can be brought to the notice of the people who are making the decisions, particularly when you take into consideration the phenomenon of chemical trauma that results from consuming foods. I would just like to quote from a document that I have which issues a warning that:

speech.para: There are direct results of environmental impacts of chemicals, especially the combined multiples of pesticides and herbicides used in the residential environment and also in the multiple residues of food. The combined levels of disrupting chemicals has never been tested in the determined public safety era.

I will speak about those issues later in the committee stage debate. So we have a changing disability, and eligibility rules will not make the actual problem go away. We need to very clearly define the standards. Where codes of practice are implemented and used, they have to be used in such as way that they will take into consideration the impact of the genetically modified portion of the foods and the chemical content or residue of the foods on the people who are consuming them.

talk.start.para: —I may be accused of stating the obvious when I say that I am attracted to Senator Stott Despoja's proposition. It is consistent with what the Labor Party has sought to do through our amendments, which have been accepted by the government, to make it clear that there is a difference between the code of practice and a standard and that there is no diminution in the primary status of food standards. The parliamentary secretary correctly makes the point that it may not be necessary, but I do not see any harm in supporting it, in the sense that it reinforces what we have been about during the debate. The Labor opposition will support the amendment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move Democrat amendment No. 2:

speech.para: Schedule 1, item 9, page 6 (line 8), at the end of paragraph (i), add ", including the publication of information to increase public awareness of food standards and food labels".

Essentially, this amendment is designed to strengthen the educative role of the ANZFA. The need for the Australian community to have educative tools and campaigns specifically to increase public awareness of food standards and to be able to extract meaningful nutritional, allergenic and other information from food labels and products has been identified by health professionals, nutritionists, dietitians and educators throughout the community. This amendment is intended to clarify and include food standards and food labels as part of the ANZFA's educative activities. It is not restricted to only those activities. For example, when gene food labelling is implemented, consumers will need to know specifically what the statement `may contain GM ingredients' means—if this term is adopted—or likewise for any other term. The ANZFA should provide information in supermarkets and any other accessible means about what these labels actually mean.

Another area of specific concern that individuals, consumer groups and health professionals have is the way that labels will accompany foods which have been irradiated or which contain ingredients which have been irradiated. Again, that is another debate that has been ongoing in the community and even in this place. The Democrats have put on record our concerns with that whole debate and recent decisions. The potential for misunderstanding a label that states `contains ionised ingredients' or `treated with ionised electrons' as was put forward as a possibility I believe by Senator Herron in his response to my question on notice on food irradiation is very likely. Many fear that some in the community could interpret such a label as meaning `containing iron', or being some kind of fortified iron product. So education on food labels and standards is integral to facilitating consumers' individual right to choose what they consume. I think that must be the bottom line at the end of the day—that consumers have information, they have education, so they can make an informed choice.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the intent with which Senator Stott Despoja has proposed this amendment but, frankly, it is unnecessary as an elaboration of section 7(1) of the act and is unnecessarily prescriptive. I think the activities of ANZFA in the area of public awareness and education are very good and need to be encouraged and supported. For example, yesterday I had the opportunity to launch the official Food Additives Shoppers Guide , a document which is a suitable size for a purse or a pocket and which, in some 78 concise pages, gives a great deal of information on food additives. It is an excellent publication prepared under the auspices of ANZFA. Similarly, in many of the areas that ANZFA does operate, the information is comprehensively available on the ANZFA web site. Looking at the number of hits on the ANZFA web side, I am sure that interested groups and consumer organisations are accessing that information readily and from time to time.

speech.para: I can assure Senator Stott Despoja that when the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council considers any proposal that comes before us—and certainly the current issues that are being addressed by that council with regard to genetically modified foods and a range of other issues which impact on labelling—this whole issue of public sensitivi ty, public awareness and education of the public is looked at on each and every occasion and on each and every agenda item comprehensively. I would submit that this amendment does not make any real contribution to the effect of the act and consequently the government does not support it.

talk.start.para: —I support the amendment moved by the Democrats. In doing so, I concur with the minister's comments that ANZFA should be commended for the work it is doing in getting information out to the public. However, I would like to raise a couple of issues on labelling which I believe are very important and need to be taken into consideration when dealing with food standards. The first involves what are called `substantial equivalents'. The part that substantial equivalence plays in the assessment of whether food is suitable for human consumption, I do not believe, has been adequately aired in the public arena.

speech.para: I will quote from a document by Eric Millstone, Eric Bruner and Sue Meyer, who clearly state that the concept of substantial equivalence emerged in response to the challenge confronting regulatory authorities in the early 1990s. They say:
Biotechnology companies had developed several GM foods and, to reassure their customers, wanted official approval for their introduction. But the government statutes did not cover GM food.
I am referring to America. They continue:
Nor did they provide the authority to regulate those innovations. Legislation could be amended but would not address the core problem of how to assess the risks.

One obvious solution at the time would have been for legislators to have treated GM food in the same way as novel chemical compounds, such as pharmaceuticals, pesticides and food additives, and required companies to conduct a range of toxic tests, the evidence from which could be used to set the acceptable daily intake of those compounds. Regulations could then have been introduced to ensure that those levels were not exceeded.

The adoption of the concept of substantial equivalence by governments of industrialised countries signalled to the GM food industry that, as long as the companies did not try to market GM food with a grossly different chemical composition from foods already available in the market, the GM food products would be permitted without any—I emphasise this—scientific or chemical analysis. The substantial equivalence concept was also intended to reassure customers, but it is not clear that it has actually served its purpose.

I bring to the Senate's attention an issue where I believe this is very relevant. Unfortunately, scientists have not yet been able to reliably predict the biochemical or toxic effects of GM food from a knowledge of its chemical composition. Scientists are saying to us that they cannot look at a food's chemical composition and reliably give us an indication of its ability to be used for human consumption in the food industry. They go on to say:

For example, recent work on the genetics of commercial grape varieties showed that despite detailed knowledge going back for centuries of the chemistry and flavour of the grapes and the wines, the relationship between the genetics of the grapes and their flavour is still not understood.

So even in the wine industry they cannot give you a linkage between the chemical and any toxic compounds that would be created through those genetically modified foods. Relying on the concept of substantial equivalence is, therefore, merely wishful thinking. It is tantamount to pretending to have adequate grounds on which to judge whether or not the products are safe. Scientists are clearly saying to us that this is not the case.

Another issue that the chamber needs to address, particularly in relation to labelling, is the actual tests being carried out on these genetically modified foods. There is a reasonable amount of scientific and general consumer knowledge about soya beans. We all know that certain soya beans have been genetically modified to withstand Round Up. What is not understood in the public arena is that the tests to check whether they are substantially equivalent are carried out on soya beans produced under laboratory conditions which have not been sprayed with Round Up, or glyphosphate. The soya bean has been grown for many applications in various countries around the world. Its substantial equivalence is based on a laboratory test under which the soya beans tested have never been sprayed with the glyphosphate they are genetically engineered to resist.

It is very clear that conflicting information is coming through from people who require that their food be assessed for human consumption. In the scientific data placed in the marketplace for public perusal, there is an inconsistency between the soya beans tested and found to be substantially equivalent and the actual soya beans grown in broadacre that are sprayed with glyphosphate. To my knowledge, no tests whatsoever have been done on the beans that have been sprayed with the glyphosphate. When you come back to my earlier comment on the previous amendment, that is where it becomes very important in relation to chemical sensitivity. I believe that the Democrats amendment, which requires the publication of information to increase public awareness on the actual food standards and the labels, is not only desirable but necessary.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I commend Senator Harris on his contribution. He did not get an opportunity to give a speech in the second reading debate. I congratulate you, Senator Harris, for putting some of those issues on record. The example of soya beans and certainly the case of Monsanto illustrate wonderfully the social, health, environmental and even cultural issues that we are dealing with in relation to the debate about genetically modified foods—GMOs—more generally and specifically in relation to labelling.

speech.para: I thank the minister for his response to my amendment and I do acknowledge, as indeed the previous speaker did, the work of ANZFA in relation to current education activities. I certainly commend the web site. I am very happy to hear that there are lots of hits on that site. That is very important and certainly so is the booklet. I commend Senator Tambling on the launch of the booklet. That was very savvy marketing, Senator Tambling. I almost expected you to say, given this is a food debate, `Here is one I prepared earlier,' and flash that around. But prescriptive? How can this be prescriptive? This talks about including the publication of information to increase public awareness of food standards and food labels. This is not restricting them; this is not prescribing these things only. It is including them. I think to describe that as prescriptive is truly extraordinary.

Earlier, in the second reading debate stage, the minister mentioned that this is the first phase. The Democrats acknowledge that. The issue of biotechnology is a huge issue that confronts Australians and the world. I understand there are other regulatory regimes being considered or put into place. I talked about the office of the gene regulator. All of these issues will have to be dealt with. I look forward to not only the ensuing debate on food labelling and genetically modified organisms but the broader biotechnology debate. However, the Democrats would have more confidence in the statements from this government—this is the first stage, there is a lot happening and there is reason for public confidence—if we had not seen what I view as a rather short-sighted approach to this debate in the contemporary history of this parliament. People would be more than aware of the Democrats' attempts on at least two occasions to set up some kind of committee reference on these broader biotechnology issues.

Indeed, on the Notice Paper now there is another opportunity for the government and the opposition to broadly discuss these issues of biotechnology in a debate that we will have this week, I hope. People would be aware that I have moved that we should have a Senate select committee investigating some of these biotech issues and looking at issues like the implementation of the labelling of genetically modified foods and products. We should be looking at the precautionary principle. We should be looking at environmental health and social, cultural, religious—if you like—and moral consequences, because all of these things are bound up in this debate. It is not about being sensationalist; it is not about scaremongering; it is not about perpetuating fear in the community. The last thing we want to see are the kind of `Frankenfoods' headlines that we have seen in places around the world. It is about recognising some of the fears that the community has. But it is not just fear; it is also that consumers get very angry when they do not have adequate information. I do not think consumers necessarily want to reject GMOs. But I do think they want to know when they are buying them and when they are eating them—when they are putting them into their bodies, when they are ingesting them in some way. I think as consumers they have that right.

I think this government should learn from overseas examples. We have seen what has happened in Europe and specifically in places like the UK. I realise there is perhaps a different cultural and political environment there. Certainly, when you look at issues like BSE, perhaps there are reasons that they have reacted more strongly than other parts of the world. But I do not think we can afford to ignore those kinds of very human, public, angered, sometimes almost activist and even terrorist actions and responses to the GMO debate. It is a responsible government that takes on board those issues, and not just within the context of ANZFA or the gene regulator. There is a need for a committee inquiry into this that not just brings into this debate the health professionals, the scientists and the experts but actually involves the public, perhaps very much in the same way that the consensus conference did earlier this year in Old Parliament House in Canberra.

I take on board that this is perhaps the first phase. But that is no excuse to settle for lowest common denominator standards on a domestic or international level. It is no reason to be seen to, effectively, substitute codes of practice for standards. The minister, in response to my first amendment, stated that it was pretty obvious that a code of practice is not a standard. If it is so obvious, why are people worried about this? Why would we seek to make this clear? It is to give consumers as well as industry professionals some confidence in this legislation. I thank the Labor Party for their support on the first and second amendments and, similarly, the Independent senators. Please, let us take on board some of the lessons of other countries, even countries close to home across the Tasman. Let us not try and fool ourselves, this chamber and the public at large that somehow this is a prescriptive amendment.

talk.start.para: —I find it somewhat strange that Senator Harris is now obviously learning the wily and cunning ways of the Senate in that, obviously, he did not get the opportunity this evening to make a speech on the second reading debate so he is taking the opportunity to read it into the record through a series of amendments. I quite accept the validity of some of the points that he wishes to make about the very emotional issue that surrounds anything in the community that looks at regulating food and the delivery of food changes. The points he makes are very valid.

speech.para: It is also important to note that perhaps some of the debate with which he introduced this amendment—which I found a strange dichotomy—would really have been better saved for the notices of motion that Senator Stott Despoja already has on the Notice Paper. She gave notice on 21 October of a motion to set up a select committee on the regulation and promotion of biotechnology; and on 29 November she also gave notice of a motion to address the various issues arising from the WTO meeting in Seattle, particularly with regard to the labelling of genetically modified foods, and to pursue labelling regimes in that regard.

They are going to be very interesting debates when we do have them—and properly have them—here in the Senate. There will be many opportunities in the coming months. I can certainly inform both Senator Harris and Senator Stott Despoja that, in the debates that are currently going on in the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council, which comprises the 10 health ministers of the Commonwealth, New Zealand and each of the state and territory jurisdictions, the whole development of these issues is being taken very cautiously, judiciously and thoroughly. There was a series of decisions last year that reflect on the points made by both Senator Harris and Senator Stott Despoja, and they again will be addressed in February, March and April of next year, when the council will have to finally resolve many of those issues—very importantly, following some significant economic studies that are currently under way. They have just been commissioned by the council itself.

The legislation we are dealing with this afternoon is much the same as the legislation that was introduced last March. I would anticipate that in February or March of next year the government's initiatives in biotechnology will be on the table before this parliament, and I am certain that all senators are going to take a very keen interest in that biotechnology legislation and in the progress that the government is making in the establishment of the office of the gene technology regulator and how that will flow through. That again will impact on this very broad issue.

But in relation to the issue before us—let me return and not do what Senator Harris is doing and take a lot of time putting other issues up—we are looking specifically at the Democrat amendment with regard to public information and awareness. I would contend that the work that ANZFA already conducts and that is already well designated under its legislation is there, and that this particular amendment on this occasion is unnecessary.

talk.start.para: —I will break with precedent, and address my remarks purely to the amendment. I indicate on behalf of the Labor opposition that we are prepared to support the amendment. It seems to me that it is only an additional set of words, including publication of information to increase public awareness of food standards and food labels. We think that strengthens the educational role given to ANZFA by spelling out those functions. If food labelling is to work, we need to support it so that consumers are properly educated about what to look for. This amendment just strengthens ANZFA's role in getting out there and promoting public awareness. We think it adds to the efficacy of the bill and ANZFA's role, and we are prepared to support it on that basis.

—I will just respond to Senator Tambling's remark: no, I most certainly have not made a second reading debate speech; it is the first one now that is sitting in the drawer up in my office after I missed the call. We can put that down to ineptness or just being new.

speech.para: I would like to bring the attention of senators back to the amendment that has been put before us by the Democrats. It is dealing with the responsibilities of and the requirements for these companies to put on the public record all of the available information. It is in that sense that I raise the issues in relation to the testing. The testing of these different foods is integral to the standards that are applied to them and whether these standards become a code of practice. Therefore it is extremely important that the public is well informed so that they can make their decision as to whether they consume these products or not. I reiterate that it is in relation to the issue of public awareness that I fully support the Democrats amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move Democrat amendment No. 3:

speech.para: (3) Schedule 1, item 16, page 8 (line 26) to page 9 (line 7), omit subsection (2), substitute:
(2) In developing food regulatory measures and variations of food regulatory measures, the Authority may also have regard to the following (in descending priority order):
(a) the need for standards to be based on risk analysis using the best available scientific evidence;
(b) the promotion of fair trading in food;
(c) the desirability of an efficient and internationally competitive food industry.
(d) the promotion of consistency between domestic and international food standards;

This amendment was referred to during the speeches in the second reading debate. The intention behind the amendment is to strengthen the bill's commitment to public health and safety and to reduce the possible conflict between consumer and industry interests. The amendment is to section 10, as amended by the Labor Party in the other place. The amendment is intended to concentrate consideration of the authority developing food regulatory measures to those matters stated in part 1 of the act. They include the protection of public health and safety, the provision of adequate information relating to food to enable consumers to make informed choices, and the prevention of misleading or deceptive conduct. We support those particular principles.

The Democrats amendment states in its current form that `the Authority may'—but I am happy to adopt Senator Brown's suggestion of changing that to `the Authority should'—have regard to a number of things, first and foremost `the need for standards to be based on risk analysis using the best available scientific evidence'. That is followed by `the promotion of fair trading in food', `the desirability of an efficient and internationally competitive food industry', and lastly `the promotion of consistency between domestic and international food standards'. I wish to amend my amendment so that instead of `may' in the first sentence of the amendment—

talk.start.para: —Are you going to take out `may also' so that it reads `the Authority should have regard'—
—Yes.
—Are you leaving in `also'?

—I think `also' was intended to remain in there—`should also have regard to the following'. And then the further addition is to part (a) of that. After `available scientific evidence', it should read `and the precautionary principle'. I thank Senator Brown for his indication that he would support the amendment with those additions, and I am quite happy to adopt them. Again, I think this amendment is quite clear.
—Has everybody taken down the amendment changes? Senator Stott Despoja.
—It sounds as though people are aware of the proposed changes, and I hope that people will support the proposed changes in the interests of public health and safety.

—Changing the `must' to `may' or `should' is not desirable, as it removes the compulsion on the authority to consider these matters in the development of food regulatory measures. I am rather surprised by that. I would have thought that the word `must' has more strength than either `may' or `should', and it is already there. These are matters that the authority should rightly consider in developing appropriate food regulatory measures. Without these safeguards, it could be unjustifiably prescriptive and costly.

speech.para: Similarly, Senator Stott Despoja has suggested adding to paragraph (a) the words `and the precautionary principle'. Unfortunately, that is a term that is often used very generally and is not one that is defined or has any specific or special meaning. It may well have a meaning for Senator Brown that is different for Senator Stott Despoja that is different for Senator Harris or different for me. I think that on this occasion it is not appropriately thought through or appropriately defined. So the government does not support the proposed changes, as initially they certainly water down the intent of the section.

talk.start.para: —I certainly take on board the minister's concerns. I am not sure if the government is going to support this amendment anyway, regardless of how it is amended, but I seek the indulgence of the chamber to change that word to `must', on advice. I think that is a preferable option.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I realise that this is one of the difficulties of doing this sort of thing on the run. I would like a clear indication of what the final Democrat amendment is, because I am not at all clear on it. My intention at this stage is to vote against it unless convinced, but it seems to be such a movable feast at the moment that I am not clear. I think Senator Stott Despoja should make it very clear what the amendment is.
—I will make it clear from the chair. Amendment No. 3 will read, as it is proposed at the moment:

interjection.para: In developing food regulatory measures and variations of food regulatory measures, the Authority must also have regard to the following (in descending priority order):
(a) the need for standards to be based on risk analysis using the best available scientific evidence and the precautionary principle;

talk.start.para: —I wish to assure Senator Evans that that is the final draft of the amendment. I am pleased to hear that he is considering supporting the amendment. My understanding from what I had heard was that we were not actually getting your support, so I would hate to think that you were dressing up your opposition to this amendment on the basis of some last-minute changes as opposed to the fact we are indeed amending an amendment that was moved successfully in a deal between the government and the Labor Party in the other house. We acknowledge that the Labor Party and the government in their dealings have improved this bill, and we commend them on those efforts. We think this amendment would actually strengthen some of the desires behind the Labor Party and government changes in this new version of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill. I do hope that the opposition is still keeping a reasonably open mind on this one, because I think all of these issues—scientific evidence, precautionary principle, fair trading, efficient and internationally competitive food industry and the promotion of consistency between domestic and international food standards—are things that we all should be supporting.

—In speaking to the amendment to the amendment, I would like to raise the issue of the precautionary principle, particularly in relation to comments that I made earlier. We are talking about food; we are talking about people consuming these products. When we have issues like the one I raised earlier, where we were actually having one group of soya beans tested and another group of beans being submitted to the public for consumption, it becomes very important for the precautionary principle to actually be applied to these tests. I have some very clear indications that I could bring to the notice of the chamber now, but I understand we are only voting on the amendment to the amendment.
—It is the whole amendment.

—If we are doing the whole amendment, I seek the indulgence of the chamber to speak for a couple of moments on what I believe is the difference between the risk analysis and the thing I spoke on earlier, the issue of substantial equivalence. This becomes particularly important when you look at the two scientific processes that are actually followed and, following from that, the regulatory requirements—I am now referring to the American requirements—that require substantial testing for a product to pass through the risk analysis process. This can take up to five years. It requires testing both within the laboratory and then through human trials. The example I would like to bring to the committee's notice is a product that was released for public consumption in 1989 by the Showa Denko KK marketing group. It is the product tryptophan. I will quote from the document I have, for the benefit of the Senate:

speech.para: For instance, in 1989 Showa Denko K.K. marketed tryptophan that had been produced in genetically engineered bacteria as a nutritional supplement in the USA.
It was very clearly a food—it was a nutritional supplement. The quote continues:
When this product was placed on the market, it made thousands of consumers ill. Of these, 1500 were permanently disabled and 37 died—
- as a result of consuming it. To continue:
Analysis by high pressure liquid chromatography indicated that this product was more than 99.6% pure tryptophan.

The scientific analysis showed that, as far as substantial equivalence was concerned, it more than passed the requirement, but because it went through on substantial equivalence and not on risk analysis the American people now have 1,500 people permanently disabled and, tragically, 37 people died. The document continues:
However, these also contained traces of a highly toxic contaminant. This toxin accounted for less than 0.01% of the total mass of the product but this was sufficient to seriously threaten health.

This is why I come back to the precautionary principle. This is the reason that ANZFA, when developing food regulatory measures, must have regard to the criteria set out in the Democrat amendment No. 3(2)(a). The standards need to be based on risk analysis. I totally support this because of that one instance.

I also strenuously stress the importance of the precautionary principle. If these products are exposed to the risk analysis process, they must go through not only a more rigid scientific assessment in the laboratory; they must also go through human trials prior to being released for public consumption. On that basis this particular tragic instance with the tryptophan would have been picked up in the human trials and we would not have had those thousands of people permanently disabled.

talk.start.para: —I will quickly respond to the amendment and Senator Stott Despoja's comments. It is fair to say that the Labor Party has attempted to deal with the Democrat amendments constructively. I have already voted for the first two and indicated to her, in querying the amendment—because it was not at all clear to me what the final wording was; there was a deal of confusion around the chamber and it was important that we get it straight—that we have thought about the propositions put. Quite frankly, what she is now moving is quite a different amendment from what was originally indicated. Our first reaction was to vote against that original amendment because we had concern about the removal of the word `must'. Having said that, we are equally concerned about the current drafting and will not be supporting this particular amendment.

speech.para: The re-inclusion of the word `must' is very important and I am glad that was adopted in the amendment moved by Senator Stott Despoja finally, but on balance we are not convinced that adding the reference to the precautionary principle is necessarily wise at this stage. We are concerned about the undefined nature of the term and how that might be applied. On balance we are not prepared to support the amendment as proposed. We will be opposing amendment No. 3 proposed by Senator Stott Despoja.

talk.start.para: —That is unfortunate. We are dealing with food here, and the precautionary principle ought to apply. When you go to the Macquarie Dictionary , the word `precaution' is defined as `a measure taken beforehand to ward off possible evil or secure good results'. The second definition is `caution employed beforehand; prudent foresight'. When you have a food authority making decisions, surely that precaution is not just something that ought to be looked at; it is exactly what should be done. The use of the term `precautionary principle' is not new. The government itself included a definition in the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill when it went through this House five months ago. Chapter 6 in that bill says that the minister must consider the precautionary principle in making decisions. It says:

speech.para: The Minister must take account of the precautionary principle in making a decision listed in the table—
which includes all sorts of things to do with controlling permits, taking action, protecting wildlife, et cetera—
to the extent he or she can do so consistently with the other provisions of this Act.

That would be a very obvious way to go. We are not dealing here with any minor matter. We are saying to the authority that we charge with looking after the food that Australians and our Kiwi cousins buy, `Make sure that you have eliminated the hazards.' Surely that is not too much to put into a piece of legislation?

The precautionary principle is accepted worldwide these days as meaning that you make sure something is safe before you proceed. I would have thought that, when it comes to food, that is the key instruction we as legislators should be giving to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority but, as I hear it, the government and the opposition are saying, `No, we cannot accept that one.' But surely this is the principle which will give people faith in this legislation: make sure you do not give the go-ahead for food regulatory measures unless, as in Senator Stott Despoja's amendment, there has been a risk analysis using the best scientific evidence available and that you act on it with the precautionary principle.

If the evidence in the risk analysis says either, `We do not know,' or `There is a hazard here,' then you do not proceed. If the evidence in the risk analysis is that there is not any hazard or threat to public health and wellbeing, then you do proceed. That is what the precautionary principle means.

Here we are saying through this amendment—and I presume the government and the opposition would not have accepted the original amendment—`Look at risk analysis.' Is it really that the government and the opposition do not want the food authority to do a risk analysis? If that is not so, why not put it into the legislation? When you have done your risk analysis, would the government and the opposition not tell the authority to use the precautionary principle? Goodness gracious, why not? This is pure commonsense, this is the heartland of this legislation and we as legislators should be using it; we should be employing these words. They are well understood and they have been used in other legislation, so why not here?

I think this is the pivotal juncture in this debate and I say this to the government: what is at stake here is not simply the health and wellbeing of people in Australia and New Zealand; it is public confidence. We as legislators are charged with the responsibility of having the public confident that we have their interests uppermost when we legislate, and there are two words here which will give that confidence: precautionary principle. They mean that you do not let tucker go through onto supermarket shelves in the wake of scientific investigations unless you know it is safe and you have taken a reasonable test to ensure that you know that there are no hazards involved. Surely that is not too much to ask. I ask the opposition just to review the decision that has been made here. I would be quite happy to ensure that we take this through the dinner break because this is very fundamental and important and I do not think that it should be just waved away.

talk.start.para: —I seek clarification from Senator Tambling as to how genetically modified food is going to be classified if in fact the substantial equivalence process is used. Can he assure the chamber and the people of Australia that, irrespective of whether a genetically modified food attains substantial equivalence, it will still be labelled within that food?

speech.para: I am referring to the American equivalent. We have in America the situation where, if a food product actually passes the substantial equivalence test, as well as not having to go through the risk analysis it is also not required to be listed as genetically modified. So I seek from the senator some assurance that, either through regulation or the government moving an amendment to the bill, we will have certainty, if ANZFA does elect to use the substantial equivalence process, that those food derivatives—whatever they are to make up the end product—are clearly labelled that they are still genetically modified even though they may attain the standard of substantial equivalence.

talk.start.para: —Could I say, in response to Senator Brown and Senator Stott Despoja, that I am all in favour of warding off evil—that sounds like a perfectly good thing—as defined by the Macquarie Dictionary . But I am not sure that that is necessarily the only reference one uses when looking at putting a term in legislation, though. As I understand it, this term is not defined in the bill and we think that causes some problems.

speech.para: I note that you thought it was the heartland of this legislation and it was at a pivotal juncture in this debate. I also note that you have not moved an amendment to include it and that Senator Stott Despoja's amendment did not include it until the last 15 minutes. So, for something that is so pivotal and as such is the heartland of this bill, I am surprised that no-one thought to raise it before.

I also think I am the only senator currently in the chamber who sat through the bill inquiry. It was not raised in submissions or in debate there. So, for such a pivotal and heartland measure, it is surprising that it had not arisen until we got an amendment on the run 15 minutes ago. But I do think that you have raised important issues and I am not unhappy about debating the role of this precautionary principle and how we might include it in the food regulatory legislation. Perhaps the time to do that is when we properly debate the full response to Blair and how we proceed with that issue.

But, in terms of making this amendment on the run without that debate, without a better definition and without broader consideration, I am not prepared to sign up to that amendment at the moment. That is a judgment made on balance. We are happy to have the debate and I am sure we will have it about Blair and, as I said in my contribution during the second reading debate, we think we should have had the wider debate first before dealing with this bill. But, on balance, we are not prepared to support this amendment to the amendment as circulated that has been raised in the last 20 minutes in the chamber. There is no problem in doing that but, in the sense of getting us to commit to it and accept the amendment, we are not prepared to do so at this stage.

talk.start.para: —I reject outright the implication from Senator Evans. The place for a Green to bring an amendment up is in the Senate and in the committee stage. I have argued for it, and if he rejects the arguments, then so be it. I stick by the words. I introduced the amendment—Senator Stott Despoja was very quick to see the advantage of it, and she is very wise to be on the record as supporting it. The opposition does not want to take the opportunity to ensure we come up with the definition. Everybody knows what `precautionary principle' means. We could have a definition in there overnight if the opposition could go along with it, but they do not want to—even though, as Senator Evans said, he has been right through the debate on this matter. So be it.

—In responding to the question posed to me by Senator Harris, I draw his attention to section 10 of the ANZFA Act. That act, which sets out the objectives of the authority in developing standards and variations of standards, reads:

speech.para: 10. The Authority, in developing standards and variations of standards, must have regard to the following objectives in descending priority order:
(a) the protection of public health and safety;
(b) the provision of adequate information relating to food to enable
consumers to make informed choices and to prevent fraud and deception;—

and then a number of other trade related matters follow. I can assure the senator that the authority is very mindful of that—it has to be, by the act. The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council, in the considerations that it is having over genetically modified food issues, is certainly taking account of the issues raised by Senator Harris.
Amendment not agreed to.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —I table the following disallowable instrument and report: Remuneration Tribunal Act—Determination No. 15 of 1999; and Remuneration Tribunal Report on Senators and Members of Parliament, Ministers and Holders of Parliamentary Office—Salaries and Allowances for Expenses of Office, dated 7 December 1999.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I have moved to take note of the report of the Department of Health and Aged Care on the operation of the Aged Care Act 1997 to enable me to refute today a press release that was put out by Mr John Anderson, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and the Deputy Prime Minister of this country. Doing this might seem a bit strange, but it is in relation to the Commonwealth regional health services program, and the provision of aged care in rural areas is a very important issue. In this press release, Mr Anderson accuses me of making remarks in the estimates committee on 1 December in relation to this program. While saying that the Labor Party is lost and does not understand the needs of country Australia, he quotes me as saying:

My dealings with rural communities suggest that when you mention the words `health' or `medical' they think hospital, hospital beds, doctor. To try and get them to make the quantum leap beyond that, to think about a range of allied health professionals and ancillary services that can be provided in a centre which do not involve beds, is almost like trying to pick the winner of next year's Melbourne Cup . . . They do not know them. They do not understand them. They do not know what they are. When you talk about occupational therapists, they think you mean a basket weaver.

He accuses me of making a major misjudgment and having a poor opinion of my constituents. Firstly, I would say to Mr Anderson and to anybody who wishes to challenge me on health issues that I am a registered nurse and I am a member of both colleges of nursing in this country. So, if you want to challenge my credentials on health, feel free, but I have professional—

talk.start.para: —You should have known better.

—Senator McGauran, I suggest you read the Hansard because, like Mr Anderson, you are taking things out of context. I will read into this Hansard the actual quotes because the department agrees with my point. Mr Anderson has had the hide and temerity to take parts of two questions and combine them and not tell the people of Australia what the department's answer is. Along with Senator Crowley, Senator Denman and Mr Blazow from the department, we were discussing this particular program. I asked:

speech.para: What educative program has been undertaken to ensure the community in Blanchetown—
which was one of the pilot programs—

understands the role of allied health workers and professionals such that they are able to utilise them fully? My dealings with rural communities suggest that when you mention the words `health' or `medical' they think hospital, hospital beds, doctor. To try and get them to make the quantum leap beyond that, to think about a range of allied health professionals and ancillary services that can be provided in a centre which do not involve beds, is almost like trying to pick the winner of next year's Melbourne Cup.
I then went on to say:
Have you undertaken some sort of program to actually educate a community as to what the range of health services can actually mean beyond hospital and doctor?
The reply from the department was:

We do have multipurpose services in the regional health service centres. We do have a consultation process. A lot of the negotiation is actually done by our state office people and state government people. We do have some funding in both this year's initiative and last year's initiative for community planning money which we will be using to help communities employ professionals to provide them with advice of that character.
They then go on:

As part of the negotiations and as part of the agreement with them, we were actually entering into a contract and really working with them over a period of time in terms of looking at expanding the range of services. In a lot of communities—you are right—they think in terms of either the GPs or in terms of hospitals. I am not sure whether they do not think of the others, but it is just that the other two have priority.
Then you can take the remainder of the bit I have been quoted from, to which Mr Blazow then says:
That is true. In Blanchetown I think people are talking about the full range. I think in fact what has been discussed is a physio service.
I then said:
That is a problem that everybody—state and federal health departments—has in getting that information out. They are not doing it.
Mr Blazow said:
Sure. That is specifically why we give additional funding for community planning, to help communities at risk with those sorts of issues.
It is quite obvious that Mr Anderson did not—

talk.start.para: —What is your argument?

—I am speaking to a report, Senator. This is the reason why Mr Anderson is totally out of the ballpark, out of character and out of all reasonable behaviour in selectively misquoting this and then going on to make aspersions about me and my relationship with rural areas. I absolutely condemn the minister for this sort of a practice. This is not the practice of a professional politician, and I am most astounded that Mr Anderson has stooped so low as to behave in such a manner. This is not the manner of behaviour that I expect from the Deputy Prime Minister of this country. (Time expired)

—In speaking to the report of the Department of Health and Aged Care on the operation of the Aged Care Act 1997, the first thing that must be said is that I am glad that the minister finally got around to it. The accountability report demanded of her under the act is 15 months late, but we do congratulate her for finally getting around to it. The report last year was not tabled. There was no excuse and no explanation given. When we raised it in the House of Representatives and questioned her about her failure to table the reports for both last year and this year, she said that it was `on the way'. Finally, a month or so later, we did get it—because we insisted on getting it—but the government had no intention of providing the report on the operation of the Aged Care Act, because it was embarrassed by what it shows. It shows a record of failure. The aged care reforms introduced in 1997 have failed the Australian public. They have failed to meet the financial targets, and they have failed to meet the needs of older Australians. The government has been very hesitant to release the information that makes that very clear.

speech.para: The opposition took the opportunity last week to table its own report, in the absence of the government meeting its statutory obligations, because we knew that the government was not at all keen on letting the Australian public know what was happening in aged care. The government's report—finally released—attempts to gloss over what is happening in aged care. It is almost as important for what it leaves out as for what it includes. There are some very misleading graphs. There is a glossing over of what is occurring in aged care in Australia.

If you want evidence of that, it was in yesterday's announcement on coalescence when, after 11 months, the government finally responded to the report of the Productivity Commission that it in fact commissioned. In doing so, it responded to one of the 18 recommendations of the Productivity Commission. The government finally got around to issuing a two-page press release, which was supposed to be its formal response to the Productivity Commission, which had so definitely found that the government's plans for coalescence in aged care were inequitable and unjust. The government's two-page press release—with a nice graph at the bottom that had nothing at all to do with the subject—was taken to be its formal response to that Productivity Commission report.

What we have seen yesterday afternoon and today is the sector expressing their dismay at the inadequacy of that report and at the failure of the Minister for Aged Care to properly deal with the issues raised. They have rejected the government's thinking that throwing $150 million at the problem will shut the sector up.

There are real underlying problems in aged care in Australia, brought about by the failure of the aged care reforms introduced in 1997. The government will not silence the sector, and they will not satisfy the needs of older Australians unless they respond to those genuine problems that exist in the sector. Trying to hide the reality by producing this report—eventually—will not help.

Throwing money at the coalescence issue to try to solve the problem will not address the real underlying problems that are at the heart of their propositions for funding of aged care in Australia. There are fundamental issues that the government has not addressed and has not responded to. The sector and older Australians will not accept that sort of response. They want something much more fundamental and comprehensive and something that admits that many of the aged care reforms have failed.

It is interesting that in this report the statistics on waiting times, which show a 30 per cent increase over the last two years, have mysteriously been omitted. You will not find them in the report, but waiting times for an aged care bed in Australia have gone up by 30 per cent. Often that means an extra three or four weeks for people to find a nursing home bed in Australia. That is because the government has not kept up with the supply needed to service the ageing in our population. Those statistics mysteriously are not in the report. I would have thought, given the statutory requirement to report, they would have been included.

There is a range of other interesting statistics that are not included, but senators will find them in the opposition's report. They are not the opposition's statistics but ones we have gleaned from estimates processes and other processes. This report seeks to gloss over the failures of their aged care reforms. It is like so many other things in aged care; they are stuck on the minister's desk for months. We do not get any activity to address the real issues of concern about providing services to the aged in Australia. The aged care reforms are failing. They are not meeting their financial targets. They are not meeting the needs of older Australians, and it is only because the opposition insisted on holding the government accountable that we have at least finally got the report, albeit 15 months late. Inadequate as it is, I welcome it as a start in holding the government accountable for the failure of the 1997 aged care reforms, and we can now hope to start to address the real problems. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
