subdebateinfo.title: Fringe Benefits Tax: Remote Area Housing

talk.start.para: —Tonight I would like to talk about a great victory for regional Australia and the cause of regional development. This victory is the decision by the government to end the fringe benefits tax on all employer provided housing in remote areas. In other countries that have a fringe benefits tax, such as Canada, the USA and South Africa, exemptions have been made for remote areas so as not to discourage regional development. However, when Paul Keating introduced the Australian version of the fringe benefits tax in 1986 no exemptions were made for remote areas, and the result has been an unmitigated disaster for regional development. That the ALP has no understanding of the needs of regional Australia could not be more clearly demonstrated than by the refusal of the Hawke-Keating government to agree to any changes in the fringe benefits tax for the remote areas of Australia. This refusal was maintained by the previous government in spite of the devastating impact that the FBT had had in reducing the populations of towns with the closure of small businesses and the loss of jobs, not to mention the introduction of fly-in fly-out work force operations and the well-documented negative impacts this practice has had on regional development.

speech.para: Other non-commercial bodies, such as local government, found themselves liable for FBT, which meant that local levels of service suffered and fewer people were able to be employed. It was not as though the Hawke-Keating government was not informed about the adverse impact of the fringe benefits tax on remote areas. Almost from the time of its introduction, the negative impacts were pointed out to the then federal government by chambers of commerce, mining companies, small business proprietors, regional development commissions, local government authorities and bodies such as the North Australia Development Conference on behalf of interested groups in Far North Queensland, the Northern Territory and the north of Western Australia.

One of the strongest voices of protest about the devastating impact of the fringe benefits tax came from the Liberal Party organisations in the Kalgoorlie electorate. I was closely involved with the Kalgoorlie north division, representing the people in the Kimberley and the Pilbara areas of Western Australia, which very early on called for remote area exemptions from this iniquitous tax and were joined by similar calls from the Kalgoorlie central division in Carnarvon and the Gascoyne and the Kalgoorlie south division, based in Kalgoorlie and the Western Australian Goldfields.

As I stated in my first speech in September 1996, the impact of the FBT has been felt across the whole of Northern Australia and the pursuit for FBT exemption on all remote area housing has been a major battle for small business. It was also in my first speech that I referred to a significant independent study that was to be carried out by the Pilbara Development Commission and which was finally released in 1999. It confirmed the adverse impacts that the FBT was having on economic development in the Pilbara.
Senator Murphy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Wait and see; you will see that it does. The report was jointly prepared by BSD Consultants, the Centre for Regional Economic Analysis of the University of Tasmania and McKessor Tieleman and Co. The report found:

speech.para: . . . the present system of FBT in Australia has had a significant negative impact on the development of the Pilbara since the introduction of this tax in 1986.

Economic modelling results indicate that without FBT (and assuming an increase in income tax to compensate for FBT) the gross output of the region would have been 3.4% higher than under the existing system, over 670 additional jobs (supporting 1400 residents) would have been created, and an additional $14.5 million would have been invested and over $413 million in additional consumption expenditure would have been incurred.
This is the equivalent of an additional $50,000 for every retail establishment in the region. It is estimated that FBT cost business enterprises the equivalent of four jobs per establishment.

Well done, Paul Keating! These findings strongly indicate that regional development has suffered substantially through the introduction of the FBT, and it was certainly no overestimation when the current chairman of the PDC, Mr Piercy, recently described the decision by the federal government to exempt all employer provided housing from FBT as a major economic breakthrough for remote Australia.

As a result of the FBT, the mining industry introduced fly-in fly-out operations, which have had a quite devastating effect on the development of new towns. It has meant, for example, that no new towns have been built around mining operations that have been established since this tax was introduced. Had the FBT been in place in the 1960s, none of the new towns which were constructed in the Pilbara, such as Newman, Tom Price, Paraburdoo or Pannawonica, would have been built, and no doubt the new port towns of Karratha, Dampier and Wickham would have been much smaller centres than they are today.

The impact of FBT on local government in remote areas was also quite devastating. Because local government has to provide subsidies to attract employees, they found themselves liable for large amounts of FBT. For example, the Port Hedland town council had an FBT bill of around $300,000—money which could have been better spent on community services and the employment of more staff.
It is very clear when you look at these facts that FBT has had a very negative effect on the development of regional areas. Mr Evan Adermann, a coalition MP in 1987, said that the FBT:
. . . takes no account of businesses destroyed, jobs lost and further massive costs to business in paperwork and unproductive time spent in the calculation and remission of this stupid tax.
He further stated:

If the (ALP) Government ceased for a little while from courting big business magnates and had a look at the way small business in Australia has been sold out, it might begin to see the awful cost of its actions.

Unlike the ALP, the Howard government has listened to the voice of regional Australia with respect to the adverse impact of the FBT on regional development, and it has taken steps to relieve the situation.

In 1997 the Howard government exempted the pastoral industry from FBT on housing. In 1998 remote area housing for the mining industry was also exempted from FBT, and now this exemption has been extended to include all employer-provided housing in remote areas from 1 April 2000. It has been estimated that the extension to include small businesses and local government authorities will provide a $15 million boost to employees in Australia's remote areas and will therefore assist in job creation.

In conclusion, I would like to express my thanks to the many organisations and individuals who have lobbied the federal government over many years to have the fringe benefits tax in remote areas removed. As I said in the beginning, the end of fringe benefits tax on employer-provided housing is a great victory for regional Australia and for the cause of regional development. The Howard government has abolished FBT for remote area employer-provided housing because it recognises the importance of regional development, and in abolishing FBT it has removed a major disincentive to regional development.

talk.start.para: —I want to make a few brief comments with regard to the world fly-fishing championships. First I want to congratulate the participants, from 19 countries, who came to Australia to participate in these championships. Even though the competition fishing was very tough, I think everyone enjoyed the hospitality that was shown them here. Hopefully they will go back to their respective countries and promote Australia as a good fishing destination, even though some of them did not catch any fish during the competition.

speech.para: I congratulate my team-mates Ross Stewart from Victoria, Steve Seclier from Western Australia, Andrew Scott from Victoria, Pat Kennedy from New South Wales, and our captain, Malcolm Crosse from Tasmania, for being part of the Australian team that has won this competition for the first time in its history. Ross Stewart became Australia's first individual world fly-fishing champion, and I sincerely congratulate him because it is a very important step.

Australia has always prided itself on being a fairly good fishing nation. It is unfortunate that competition fly-fishing—and indeed any sport fishing—does not receive the recognition it rightly should in view of the fact that some five million people in this country participate in the sport of fishing. Other sports that have a significantly lower rate of participation quite often receive greater acknowledgment.

Other teams that made it into the medal race were France, which came second, and New Zealand, which came third. A guy from New Zealand who is now retiring from world competition, Mr Pat O'Keefe from Rotorua, won the bronze medal, so in his final world championship event his team won the bronze medal and he won the bronze medal as an individual. It was a very successful event, and I would also like to congratulate the organisers. Things ran very smoothly and, all in all, it turned out very well.
I would now like to address an entirely separate matter that I have had some involvement with over a long period of time, namely forestry.

talk.start.para: —It is a pity you weren't here for the debate, Shane.

—I acknowledge Senator Troeth's interjection about being absent for the debate. I am actually sorry that I was not here for the debate, Senator Troeth. I suspect that I probably know as much, if not more, than most people in this chamber about this issue, so I would have liked to have made a contribution. I will take what time I have left tonight to make a contribution with regard to the RFA process in an overall sense, both nationally and in my home state.

speech.para: Nationally I think the RFA process was, from its inception, a good idea. It should have been able to deliver some good outcomes; in fact in some instances it has. Unfortunately, in other areas it has not. There has been much debate and much politicking with regard to amendments moved by the opposition. In a sense, the legislation, apart from being a guarantee to the states that compensation will be paid should the Commonwealth or a state renege on the agreement, has no value. The real value is in the agreement, and that is where I have some problems.

I have said before that I have problems with regard to the processes contained in some of the regional forest agreements insofar as job creation is concerned. Job creation is fundamental to this industry in this country which, in global terms, is not a large timber supplier. We ought to be able to learn from other countries throughout the world, particularly some of the developing countries, about how not to waste and how not to use forest resources. It seems that we are incapable of doing that.

In my home state I have for many years been at the forefront of support for the timber industry, and I will continue to be. But I will not support practices that are not in the interests of the industry, the state or the people who work in the industry. Regional forest agreements were championed as being a mechanism or a process whereby, at the end of the day, job creation would occur. In respect of Tasmania, Tasmanian forest workers have lost more jobs since the RFA has been in place than at any time prior—without a major closure of a factory—to it being put in place, and that is very unfortunate. But we can analyse some of the causes for that, and they are relatively easy to be analysed.

What has happened to the timber industry in Tasmania—and, unfortunately, in some other states—is that it has become driven by one or two major companies. It has been taken in a direction that has not been in the interests of the state, neither economically nor socially. It has not been in the interests of the good utilisation of a natural resource. Tasmania has been through the mill in respect of inquiries, investigations and reviews on forest issues—probably more so than any other state in Australia—so we ought to have some knowledge about what should be happening.

As I said, I have been pursuing changes. When I have looked at the cost of timber, particularly in Europe, I have seen, as I have said before, logs of timber sold in log form for three, four and sometimes as much as 100 times more than the same wood of the same structure that we sell in our state to the European market and to the Chinese market. Everybody says, `China doesn't want wood.' Of course, they want wood. It is the largest and most populated country in the world—of course, they need wood. The problem for us is that we have to look at the marketing processes and we have to look at utilisation. Last year I saw a single log sold in Germany for $A43,000, and I could get the same log—not known as the same species, but structurally exactly the same sort of wood—from a forest in the north-west of Tasmania for less than $7 per cubic metre, making the same size log worth in the vicinity of $100. It really begs the question: why is this happening?

We in Tasmania had a review of forest practices, which was announced by the government over a year ago. It was conducted and the report was handed down, I think, in early May. Despite the fact that the person who conducted the review had previously conducted another review and found no problem associated with the conduct and management of the commercial forests in Tasmania, he handed down a review that was, in many respects, quite condemning of the practices and the utilisation practices that we have in Tasmania. I have waited a long time to get a state government response in respect of that. We now have a ministerial statement and a press release. I accept that any government has to consider these things in due course, but the unfortunate aspect of this is that, at this juncture, it seems that the government is only going to regurgitate the things of the past: it is going to refer it off to another committee. Given our experience with the number of reviews and inquiries, I had hoped that we would have been able to move on. I still hope—in many ways as a fishermen you always have to be the supreme optimist because you never know when you are going to catch one—that the government will move forward. I put them on notice, as I have done before, that if they do not move forward this will become a major political issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Food Additives Shoppers Guide , prepared under the auspices of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, is one of those must-have publications for anyone who wants to find out more about food additives. Despite its small size, it is big on information and practicality. Madam President, I had the opportunity to officially launch this in your electorate at the Canberra Centre yesterday, and it met with a very positive and good response. I will table a copy of it for the records of the Senate.

speech.para: As I was browsing through the guide, it struck me that it might also be an invaluable tool for Scrabble enthusiasts. It certainly contains a lot of interesting, long words that might improve not only one's knowledge about food additives but also one's word score. Knowing about food additives is particularly important for any mum and dad or their kids who may be allergic to certain food additives. Information on food additives can also be important in managing certain medical conditions and food intolerances or allergies.

I wear a number of different hats in this parliament. My responsibilities include the regulation of standards for food and medicines in Australia and responsibility for the Australia New Zealand Food Authority—the sponsor of this particular guide, as it is often called—and the Therapeutic Goods Administration. In these various roles I am constantly being informed of new facts, new figures, new technologies and new developments. Today, facts and figures are certainly centre stage—in a very literal sense in this guide.

Exactly what are food additives and food additive numbers? What do they do? What do they mean? And why do we need them? Put simply, `food additive' is the umbrella term that covers ingredients deliberately added to foods today for a range of reasons, such as to improve taste, to stop foods from drying out, to protect us from food poisoning and to keep our food fresh. Food additives include colourings, sweeteners, food acids, flavourings, thickeners and vegetable gums. We can see from this guide that food additives also include preservatives.

In days gone by, people relied on traditional preserving methods so they could store foods and survive through times of adversity. While some of these methods are still used today for preserving jams, vegetables and some fermented meats, we now rely primarily on additives in our processed foods and drinks to carry out this function. Over the years, food additives have copped some bad publicity. Mostly, the criticism has been unwarranted. In fact, additives have a lot of advantages. One of the benefits is that we can enjoy a wide range of foods throughout the year. In many cases, this extension of availability would not be possible without food additives.

A good example is to look at the way jams have changed. Traditionally, sugar was used as the preservative in jams. These days, people want jams without sugar, either as low kilojoule alternatives or for special dietary needs. So with the help of additives, artificial sweeteners replace the sugar, humectants are used so the jam has a smooth taste, thickeners give it bulk, and preservatives stop it going off once the jam is opened. I have just given an example of where the food additives used are synthetic, but it should be remembered that some substances used as additives also occur naturally. For example, citric acid can be used as a food additive. It is also present naturally in oranges.

Many people today will be familiar with a publication called 508—what's that? That booklet was the predecessor of the new guide. The `508' in the title referred to potassium chloride—a mineral salt. ANZFA has revamped that publication so it now has a more user-friendly format. In particular, in the new version, additives are now listed both alphabetically and numerically. It is still a handy pocket size, which is great because it means that you can easily take it with you when you shop. You might want to think of this guide in terms of being a `codebuster' or `codebreaker' for food additives. There are overseas publications about food additives with these sorts of names.

By law, food manufacturers are required to list on the label either the food additives code number or name or include both. These code numbers can seem a bit technical or may be meaningless or confusing for many people. This is exactly where the Food Additives Shoppers Guide comes in handy as it takes away much of the mystery surrounding the numbers. The codes are generally made up of three or four numbers. The reason food additives have code numbers is not to be difficult or to purposely hide information from consumers. It is because many additives have long and complex scientific names which are not only difficult to understand but also would take up too much space on a label. You might turn to page 63 of the guide and look at code No. 385, which is a preservative. The third word in this preservative's name is 27 letters long. Let me see if I can pronounce it correctly: ethylenediaminetetraacetate. It would be wonderful if you could put that on a Scrabble board.

The international code numbering system for food additives was developed to make identifying food additives easier rather than harder. Now let us take a practical example from the guide. If you are reading the food ingredients list of a processed food in a supermarket, you might want to know what `440' is. You can flick through the guide and see that it is pectin—a vegetable gum used in products such as jams.

When people ask me about additives and whether they are safe, I can confidently tell them, `Yes. The government would not permit them to be added to food if they weren't.' Additives have to go through stringent safety assessment procedures before they gain approval from ANZFA—the national food regulator. While additives are safe, some people in the community may experience adverse reactions to food additives. Other people have food intolerances to foods such as peanuts and milk. We are really keen for these people to know about the shoppers guide so that they can use this publication to avoid foods which may affect them. Indeed, the more practical information we have about food, the better it is for everyone. I think that was the issue being addressed in the debate just before the adjournment this evening when Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Brown tried to introduce certain principles regarding ANZFA, food and so on.

The shoppers guide is a resource which can complement the advice and information provided by health professionals such as diet itians, nutritionists and members of the medical profession. If anyone wants to be the full bottle on food additives, I would encourage them to take a look at this publication. It is on the ANZFA web site at www.anzfa.gov.au free of charge. I am told that it is also available in major retail booksellers across Australia for $3.95. It would make a very handy Christmas stocking filler. It is something that is sure to be appreciated by anyone who has an interest in knowing more about the ingredients in foods. I urge anybody with such an interest to take a close look at this guide. Next time you are in a supermarket, check out the ingredients lists on the food labels for additives and use this guide to crack the codes. Spread the word about this guide among family, friends and work colleagues, as many people need to know about it. It is, after all, something that should encourage very happy reading. I table the publication.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to speak about the ongoing consequences of the federal coalition's policy of higher education in Australia. It is no secret that regional universities are doing it tough as a result of this government's policies. Universities in regional Australia face a crisis in funding and resources caused by this government's policies. These policies, I believe, impede the role of education in regional development and increase the disadvantage faced by rural students. They are causing real damage to regional economies.

speech.para: I am saddened to say tonight—I intend to speak about the university in the Northern Territory—that the Northern Territory University at this stage is facing an increasingly tough time. By 2001, the operational funding for the Northern Territory University will have decreased by nearly $1.5 million since 1996. In a comparison of the actual 1996 operating grant to the university with the 2001 estimates derived from DETYA figures, there is a minus 4.2 per cent difference. The NTU has sustained not only cuts to operating grants but also a loss of discretionary grants and the failure of this government to supplement salaries paid in universities.

For a small regional university like the NTU, the funding reduction has had a huge impact, as both staff and students are quick to point out. I am constantly being contacted by those staff and students from the NTU who are concerned about the quality of education being provided, the continuing increase in student-staff ratios, the high turnover of staff, the less frequent lecture and tutorial contact and the outdated technology.

But it should be pointed out that this is an Australia-wide malaise in regional universities found in our higher education system. Regional universities have been trying to cope with declining student demand and problems in meeting their student targets. Increasingly expensive education has led to a reduction in demand for university places. In 1997 demand for university places fell by 4.4 per cent, and in 1998 it fell by 4.1 per cent. We know that rural students are finding it increasingly difficult to afford the cost of education and that the cost of university fees stops them from attending. The lower threshold on HECS has meant that more students from disadvantaged backgrounds are required to pay for their education.

Also worth commenting on is the fall in demand of around 10 per cent among mature aged students. So it is really the old chicken and egg scenario. Increasing costs lead to a reduction in student numbers, which leads to less funding, which leads to less staff and higher staff-student ratios, which leads to increased student dissatisfaction, which leads to a further reduction in student numbers.

The federal education minister, Dr Kemp, has previously claimed that the income available to universities is increasing, based on projections about the increasing proportion of income that comes via student fees and charges. However, as we have seen, the government's income to universities has been steadily decreasing since 1996. The government's figures show that under the current arrangements the year 2000 government funding to universities will be below 50 per cent of total operating revenue. It will be around the same level as it was in 1990.

The repercussions of this government's higher education policies are being felt across the country and no more so than at the Northern Territory University. Recently, the NTU announced the loss of 22 positions from the Faculty of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. The NTU have responded to their funding crisis—it now is a funding crisis at NTU—by reallocating valuable resources away from Aboriginal education to prop up the mainstream faculties. These redundancies have come as a direct result of the recommendations contained within the recently released Northern Territory University report of the Review Committee into the Faculty of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Indigenous Education.

The courses of FATSIS, the acronym for that faculty, have been a primary reason for indigenous enrolments at the NTU. The courses are designed to introduce indigenous students to tertiary education and to encourage them in a culturally sensitive and appropriate way to go on and change their lives and their prospects through further education. The university has decided to move the 22 positions from FATSIS, saying that special programs for Aboriginal people built up by the indigenous faculty over the last 10 years are a wasteful duplication. This has been dismissed by the staff in that faculty. The staff have expressed dissatisfaction and concern with the way that the university has implemented changes within the faculty. The composition of the implementation committee prevented the community, students and staff from playing a role in the implementation of any of the recommendations of the review.

They have expressed concern at the university's targeting of the faculty's enabling and bridging programs for early school leavers, which is something the Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory has identified as being a key area of need. It is ironic, really, that the faculty, the only freestanding faculty of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies in Australia, which gives the Northern Territory University something unique, is now the target as the university desperately seeks to reduce its costs.

FATSIS staff see the university's latest moves as attacking the faculty's integrity, which will ultimately destroy its viability and independence. It also means the loss of vital money from indigenous education programs. It is also symptomatic of the problems being faced by our regional universities. Cutting costs inevitably leads to cutting courses, which leads to less funding due to reducing the university's ability to attract students.

Education plays a critical role in regional development, and no more so than in Darwin and the Northern Territory. It supports the development of industries and enterprises through the provision of essential skills and knowledge. It provides research and analysis of key industrial and environmental factors which impact on the regions themselves. It also contributes to economic activity and job creation more efficiently than any other industry.

Cost cutting without vision, growth or planning means losing the student critical mass at the university. Fewer staff in the faculty make it even more difficult for that faculty to offer its courses in Aboriginal communities. That is important for the university if it is to attract students who may otherwise feel intimidated in places like the Casuarina campus of the Northern Territory University.

Speaking on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1999 about seven weeks ago, I painted a picture of universities struggling for funds, seeking to downsize and make staff redundant in order to cope. The loss of 22 positions at FATSIS is a direct consequence of this federal government's policies on higher education in Australia. It is disturbing that a unique Aboriginal education faculty is affected in this way at a time when we should be doing everything we possibly can to increase Aboriginal education rates, participation and retention and, even more important, the completion by those students of courses in indigenous studies in our tertiary sector.

This government needs to address the role that education plays in regional development and to develop and promote policies that support a strong, viable and publicly funded tertiary education system which is responsive to the needs of the community it serves. Education contributes to regional development more per dollar spent than any other industry. For every million dollars of turnover in education, 38 jobs are created in the economy. This government need to reassess their failed education budget and allow universities, particularly those in regional areas such as the Northern Territory, to continue to make their valuable contribution to the regional students and the regional economy.

I say that this government's policies stand condemned for what they have done to Australia's higher education sector and in particular the impact they had some years ago on the Arts Faculty of the Northern Territory University and have now had on the Faculty of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Primary Producers
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1569)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Before the goods and services tax (GST) is payable on any transaction the supply made by a taxpayer must be `in the course or furtherance of an enterprise carried on by the taxpayer' (Division 9 of A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999): if a primary producer, who has been carrying on a business for a number of years, sells all of his trading stock and equipment then GST will apply to the sale, however, does GST apply to the sale of the farm land if the farm land is sold by the farmer after he has ceased carrying on the business of primary production.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The GST legislation provides that a supply of farm land that is part of a going concern is GST-free, subject to certain conditions: the supply is for consideration; the recipient is registered or required to be registered; the supplier and the recipient have agreed in writing that the supply is of a going concern; the supplier must provide to the recipient all things necessary for the continued operation of the enterprise; and the supplier must carry on the enterprise until the date of supply. If a farmer ceases carrying on the business of primary production before the date the farm land is sold, the sale would not qualify for GST-free treatment under these provisions.
However, the sale of farm land may be GST-free even where the land is sold after the farmer has ceased carrying on the business of primary production on the land.

First, under amendments to the GST legislation recently introduced by the Government, the separate sale of farm land and improvements will be GST-free, provided a farming business has been carried out on the land for at least the period of five years preceding the supply and the buyer intends that a farming business be carried out on the land. The movable property (eg, livestock and equipment) will be subject to tax. This takes account of the normal practice for the sale of farms where the underlying land and movable property are sold separately.

Secondly, and again under amendments recently introduced, GST-free treatment applies for a separate supply of farm land where it is subdivided and provided as potential residential land to an associate (eg, a relative) for no consideration or for consideration at less than the market value and where the land has been used for farming purposes for at least five years.

GST will be payable on the sale of farm land that does not come under the above provisions, eg where the land has not been used for farming purposes for at least five years or where the land is to be sold for non-farming purposes such as residential land re-development. Property subject to tax can be sold under the usual tax rules or under the GST's margin system. Where a registered business purchases a property fully taxed, it will be able to claim an input tax credit for the tax payable thereby making the purchase effectively tax free.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Service Tax: Retirement Villages
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1574)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) How is the construction of retirement villages treated for Goods and services tax (GST) purposes.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The construction of a retirement village will be subject to GST. The sale of a new retirement village unit to a resident will be subject to GST; however, subsequent sales of that unit will be input taxed. These treatments are consistent with the more general treatment of the construction and sale of residential dwellings under the GST.

(2) Residents of retirement villages who do not require nursing or daily living activities assistance services are treated the same as residents of other rental accommodation, that is, the rental charge would be input taxed. A supply of services, including accommodation, to residents of retirement villages who require nursing or daily living activities assistance services will be GST-free.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Wheat Producers Loans
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1697)

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Can the Assistant Treasurer outline the goods and services tax (GST) arrangements for loan payments made to wheat producers through the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) in lieu of crop sales being finalised.
(2) Will the AWB need to differentiate between domestic and export wheat sales from their pool to determine what sales are subject to a GST and what sales are exempt.
(3) If it is determined that AWB loan payments are GST free, will this exemption extend to other grain growers.

(4) As many primary producers are now planning their crop rotations for the next 12 to 18 months, can the Assistant Treasurer explain what responsibilities primary producers and agricultural marketing boards have under the GST.

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Where a loan agreement is entered into with, amongst other things, loan repayments and interest charges with commercial terms, details of conditions in the event of loan default, risks borne by the lender and a genuine expectation of repayment, no GST will be applicable to the loan principal and no GST is payable on interest charges. However, the supply of the loan facility by the AWB itself will be input taxed as a financial supply.

Where a genuine loan agreement is entered into with a producer, a liability for GST on the supply of the wheat will arise either at the time the producer is paid or issues an invoice for their wheat, depending on whether the producer accounts on a cash or non-cash basis.

(2) If the AWB sells wheat directly to a non resident customer and actually exports the wheat, the supply will be GST free. The conditions which must be met to make a GST free export are that the goods are exported from Australia by the supplier within 60 days of the supplier receiving any consideration or issuing an invoice for the goods (whichever occurs first).
Export sales of wheat by the AWB will be GST free and domestic sales will be subject to the GST. Therefore, the AWB will have to account separately for these sales.

(4) Broadly, primary producers and agricultural marketing boards will have the same responsibilities as all other GST registered businesses. Each entity will have to apply for an Australian Business Number to be registered for GST. After 1 July 2000 GST will have to be remitted for taxable supplies made in the course of their business. An input tax credit will be allowed for GST paid on creditable business acquisitions. Regular returns called Business Activity Statements will need to be completed and lodged with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) (quarterly or monthly). A net payment of GST will have to be made at the same intervals. Where a business has paid out more GST than has been collected then the ATO will refund the amount within 14 days of the lodgement of the return.
